title: Ironic
lyrics:
Ironic Lyrics[Intro]
Hey, yeah, yeah
Yeah, ah-ah-ah, yeah, hey

[Verse 1]
An old man turned ninety-eight
He won the lottery and died the next day
It's a black fly in your Chardonnay
It's a death row pardon two minutes too late

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Verse 2]
Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
And as the plane crashed down
He thought, "Well, isn't this nice?"

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Bridge]
Well, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
When you think everything's okay and everything's going right
And life has a funny way of helping you out
When you think everything's gone wrong
And everything blows up in your face
You might also like[Verse 3]
A traffic jam when you're already late
A "No Smoking" sign on your cigarette break
It's like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife
It's meeting the man of my dreams
And then meeting his beautiful wife

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
A little too ironic
And yeah, I really do think

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Outro]
And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
Helping you out41Embed
annotation:
[('And who would’ve thought? It figures', [['Seemingly a throw-away line, the juxtaposition of these two contrary interjections neatly expresses the typical reaction to irony. An unexpected twist makes you say “Who would have thought?” but when you reflect it was almost inevitable (“It figures.”)']]), ('And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
 And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
 Helping you out', [['A bittersweet ending to a bittersweet song. Throughout the entire song, Alanis lists a number of sad, but at the same time, silly (and maybe sometimes ironic) situations that happen in people’s lives. The verses have a sad tone while the chorus is loud and cheerful. The outro says how helpless we are as human beings. We can plan our lives as much as we want but we can’t predict the future. We should accept that, and stop trying to control everything. Any little event can change the course of our entire life. What we should do is try to follow a certain path, but not be disappointed if we get sidetracked. That change of course might just be a blessing in disguise.']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?
 A little too ironic
 And yeah, I really do think', [['“Uh, no, we don’t,” said the English teachers of the world.

However, on the other hand, maybe the whole song really is ironic. Remember, irony is when things turn out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected. And Morrissette has just finished a song that is intended to illustrate the word “ironic” with a series of situations, except none of them actually turn out to be examples of irony. So the whole song turned out the opposite of how she expected.

In its own way, isn’t that ironic?']]), ('An old man turned ninety-eight
 He won the lottery and died the next day', [['It’s a pity that the old man, who had lived his whole life presumably in economical difficulty, had the chance to improve his lifestyle with a lottery win but he died the next day.

But is it ironic? No, it is not.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The old man had played the lottery specifically to get money to pay for heart surgery, but the excitement of finding out he’d won triggered a fatal heart attack.

Remember the definition of ironic:


using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny

strange or funny because something (such as a situation) is different from what you expected']]), ('It’s a black fly in your Chardonnay', [['Nobody wants a fly in anything they eat or drink, including a nice glass of white wine like Chardonnay. (Except of course people who enjoy eating insects.)

But that doesn’t make it ironic. Irony is when a situation turns out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected.

This MIGHT be ironic if:


You had deliberately decided to drink Chardonnay because you believed it was the beverage least likely to contain flies.
You had spent all day killing the flies in your home and, believing that you had successfully killed every single one of them, opened a bottle of Chardonnay to celebrate and discovered a fly in it.





Come on Alanis, it’s just protein!']]), ('It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife', [['Irish comedian Ed Byrne did a brilliant skit about “Ironic” back in 1998. He went to town on the lyrics, but saved his takedown of this line until last.

The best line in that song, the best line ever written, ever, has got to be the line ‘It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife’. That’s not ironic – that’s just stupid. How big is your sink, Alanis? Come on![…]What do you need a knife for? To stab the bastard who keeps leaving spoons all over your house?

Byrne went on to give a scenario in which the line would make sense:

Imagine you needed a knife for something, couldn’t find one cos all you found was ten thousand spoons and therefore couldn’t do whatever it was you needed the knife for. And then the next day, turned out that a spoon would’ve done…

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZOZG1Ob6po']]), ('Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
 He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
 He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
 And as the plane crashed down
 He thought, “Well, isn’t this nice?”', [['More tragic than ironic.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The man was in a plane crash even though he had deliberately researched and chose an airline that was noted for its safety record, like Qantas.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qmF1Lh4f3OM

However, in the end, the song accidentally gets this one right.

That’s because when the man thinks to himself, “Well, isn’t this nice…?” he is thinking the opposite of what he means. Luckily for Morrissette, this fits the other dictionary definition of ironic:

using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?', [['A lot of people say no.

Even Alanis joked about it herself in the revisited version of the song performed on the Late Show with James Corden with the line: “It’s singing "Ironic,” but there are no ironies"']]), ('It’s a death row pardon two minutes too late', [['Now that just sucks – too bad they won’t ever have to know…

This is incredibly tragic and all too real. According to a study by Northwestern University, at least 39 innocent people have been wrongfully executed in the United States.

It is tragic, unjust, and worrisome. BUT – is it ironic? No.']])]

title: Not the Doctor
lyrics:
Not the Doctor Lyrics[Verse 1]
I don't wanna be the filler if the void is solely yours
I don't wanna be your glass
Of single malt whiskey hidden in the bottom drawer
And I don't wanna be a bandage if the wound is not mine
Lend me some fresh air
I don't wanna be adored for what I merely represent to you
I don't wanna be your babysitter
You're a very big boy now
I don't wanna be your mother
I didn't carry you in my womb for nine months
Show me the back door
[Chorus]
Visiting hours are nine to five
And if I show up at ten past six, well, I
Already know that you'd find some way to sneak me in and oh
Mind the empty bottle with the holes along the bottom
You see, it's too much to ask for
And I am not the doctor
(Oh, I am not the, oh)

[Verse 2]
I don't wanna be the sweeper
Of the egg shells that you walk upon
And I don't wanna be your other half
I believe that one and one make two
I don't wanna be your food or the light
From the fridge on your face at midnight, hey
What are you hungry for?
I don't wanna be the glue that holds your pieces together
I don't wanna be your idol
See, this pedestal is high, and I'm afraid of heights
I don't wanna be lived through a vicarious occasion
Please, open the window

[Chorus]
Visiting hours are nine to five
And if I show up at ten past six, well, I
Already know that you'd find some way to sneak me in and oh
Mind the empty bottle with the holes along the bottom
You see, it's too much to ask for
And I am not the doctor
(Oh, I am not the, oh)
You might also like[Verse 3]
I don't wanna live on 'Someday'
When my motto is 'Last Week', and I
I don't wanna be responsible
For your fractured heart and its wounded beat
And I don't wanna be a substitute
For the smoke you've been inhaling
Well, what do you thank me, what do you thank me for?

[Chorus]
Visiting hours are nine to five
And if I show up at ten past six, well, I
Already know that you'd find some way to sneak me in and oh
Mind the empty bottle with the holes along the bottom
You see, it's too much to ask for
And I am not the doctor
(Ooh, I am not the, oh)3Embed
annotation:
[('I don’t wanna live on ‘Someday’
 When my motto is ‘Last Week’', [['Addicts frequently say they’ll “someday” get over their addictions. Alanis wants the problem solved “last week” as an absolute rather than a possibility.']]), ('For your fractured heart and its wounded beat
 And I don’t wanna be a substitute
 For the smoke you’ve been inhaling
 Well, what do you thank me, what do you thank me for?', [['She doesn’t want to be the sole replacement for this person’s vice, and she doesn’t want to have the responsibility of taking care of them – and failing – on her shoulders.']]), ('You see, it’s too much to ask for
 And I am not the doctor
 (Oh, I am not the, oh)', [['Alanis is just a woman, and indicated throughout the song that she’s not a nanny or babysitter. The addict she’s speaking to is asking too much of her and stretching her too thin, when she’s not even a doctor who can actually help with the alcoholism.']]), ('Mind the empty bottle with the holes along the bottom', [['According to Definitely Alanis the bottle is used to represent the self esteem of a clingy lover. No matter how much she tries to build him up, he knocks himself down again, leading to a no-win situation. Similarly, no matter how often you fill a bottle with holes in it, it will inevitably empty itself. Alanis says that its not only written to past boyfriends, but to herself as well. “At the same time that I’m writing it to someone else, I’m writing it to myself in a round about way.”']]), ('I don’t wanna be your babysitter
 You’re a very big boy now', [['The person she’s talking about is grown, and Alanis indicates she wants an equal who doesn’t need to be taken care of as if they were a child.']]), ('I don’t wanna be adored for what I merely represent to you', [['Rather than Alanis herself being appreciated, the person she’s talking about appreciates an image of her they created in their heaad – ie they adore the IDEA of her, and how to them she represents being taken care of, not her herself.']]), ('And I don’t wanna be a bandage if the wound is not mine', [['Alanis does not want to be responsible for healing anyone but herself – hence the later line about not being the doctor.']]), ('Visiting hours are nine to five
 And if I show up at ten past six, well, I
 Already know that you’d find some way to sneak me in and oh', [['“Visiting hours” are times where a patient in a facility (in this instance likely a rehab facility based on mentions of alcohol) are able to see their family and friends.

If Alanis is late, the person she’s speaking about is still going to figure out a way to see her regardless. This desperate resourcefulness is something else that comes with addictions.']]), ('I don’t wanna be your food or the light
 From the fridge on your face at midnight, hey
 What are you hungry for?', [['People sometimes have the urge to eat or snack late at night, most of the time it isn’t something they need – it’s just to satisfy an ephemeral urge. She doesn’t want to be a mere snack; consumed and forgotten.

The light of the fridge (that turns on when it’s open) refers to indecision regarding which food to snack on. She doesn’t want to be a purgatory between relationships, that is she doesn’t want to be someone you turn to when you’re indecisive.

Lastly, Alanis is asking: what do you want to eat? And by extension, what do you truly WANT?']]), ('And I don’t wanna be your other half
 I believe that one and one make two', [['Alanis makes it very clear here that she is a whole person, not the half of someone else.  This is a very important, feminist driven line because a relationship isn’t exactly healthy if both people in it solely depend on each other to be happy in life.']])]

title: Perfect
lyrics:
Perfect Lyrics[Verse 1]
Sometimes is never quite enough
If you're flawless, then you'll win my love
Don't forget to win first place
Don't forget to keep that smile on your face

[Chorus]
Be a good boy
Try a little harder
You've got to measure up
Make me prouder
[Verse 2]
How long before you screw it up?
And how many times do I have to tell you
To hurry up?
With everything I do for you
The least you can do is keep quiet

[Chorus]
Be a good girl
You gotta try a little harder
That simply wasn't good enough
To make us proud

[Bridge]
I'll live through you
I'll make you what I never was
If you're the best, then maybe so am I
Compared to him, compared to her
I'm doing this for your own damn good
You'll make up for what I blew
What's the problem? Why are you crying?

[Chorus]
Be a good boy
Push a little farther now
That wasn't fast enough
To make us happy
We'll love you just the way you are
If you're perfectYou might also like4Embed

title: Front Row
lyrics:
Front Row Lyrics[Intro]
I know he's blood but you can still turn him away
You don't owe him anything

[Verse 1]
Do you go to the dungeon
To find out how to make peace
With your days in the dungeon?
Writing a letter to you
Didn't make me feel any more peaceful
Than how I felt when we weren't speaking
Because I didn't cop to what I did
I can't love you 'cause we're supposed to have professional boundaries
I’d like you to be schooled and in awe
As though you were kissed by God
Full on the lips
[Chorus]
I'm in the front row
The front row with popcorn
I get to see you
See you, close up

[Hidden Lyrics in Chorus Background]
(I’m too tired to recount the unpleasantries
One by one minute, I want to banish you
The next I want to be on a deserted island
With you, along with my three favorite CDs
Ambivalent, yet in your bed, we've yet to acknowledge what really happened)

[Verse 2]
Slid into the ditch
I have this overwhelming loss of ambition
We said, "Let's name thirty good reasons
Why we shouldn't be together"
I started by saying things like, "You smoke" "You live in New Jersey"
You started saying things like, "You belong to the world"
All of which could have been easily refuted
But the conversation was hypothetical
I am totally short of breath for you
Why can't you shut your stuff off?

[Chorus]
I'm in the front row
The front row with popcorn
I get to see you
See you, close up
You might also like[Hidden Lyrics in Chorus Background]
(And I laughed until my lungs hurt
I love how you bust my chops
You don't always feel seen
Sometimes you feel erasable
Unfortunately, I cannot reciprocate in my current state
I think we should be careful of how much time we spend together)

[Verse 3]
For a while while I’m speaking
You know how much you hate to be interrupted
Maybe spend some time alone
Fill up your proverbial cup so that it doesn't always have to be about you
I've been wanting your undivided attention
I like the fact that you're nothing like me
Are you not burdened by the lack of perspective people have of your charmed life seemingly?

[Chorus]
I'm in the front row
The front row with popcorn
I get to see you
See you, close up

[Hidden Lyrics in Chorus Background]
(You never meant to be ungrateful
Nor held up to be whipped or wept for certainly
Not analyzed, prodded at more ways than one
Apparently you've been misrepresented
Dealing with the concept of arrows being slung
Towards your outrageous fortune)
[Verse 4]
Hey, I’m not mad at you guardian
I’m mad at myself for spending so much time with you and your Jekyll and Hydeness
I’m glad I figuratively slapped you on the wrist
You laughed a wicked laugh and said, "Come here, let me clip your wings!"
(I know he's blood but you can still turn him away, you don't owe him anything)
"Raise the roof" he yelled, "Yeah, raise the roof!", I yelled back
(Unfortunately you needed a health scare to reprioritize)
No thanks to the soap box
Having me rile against them won't make an ounce of difference

[Chorus]
I'm in the front row
The front row with popcorn
I get to see you
See you, close up

[Hidden Lyrics in Chorus Background]
Oh the things I’ve done for you
Many a stitch a friend a man's been left for you
Oh the books I’ve read for you
The tongues I’ve bitten for you
Many a new city for you
Many a risk taken for you
Not a single regret1Embed
annotation:
[('Do you go to the dungeon
 To find out how to make peace
 With your days in the dungeon?', [['Simply wondering if it’s going to take going back to the difficult places and/or speaking to the difficult people from her past to get over whatever happened.']]), ('You started saying things like, “You belong to the world”', [['Kevin Smith meant that she was huge at the moment because of her album “Jagged Little Pill”, which made her a worlwide know star.']]), ('We said, ”Let’s name thirty good reasons
 Why we shouldn’t be together”', [['This line refers to a conversation Alanis Morissette and director Kevin Smith had over the phone about why they weren’t together as a couple as they seemed to get along so well.']])]

title: Baba
lyrics:
Baba Lyrics[Verse 1]
I've seen them kneel with bated breath for their ritual
I've watched this experience raise them to pseudo higher levels
I've watched them leave their families in pursuit of your nirvana
I've seen them coming to line up from Switzerland and America

[Chorus]
How long will this take, baba?
And how long have we been sleeping?
Do you see me hanging on to every word you say?
How soon will I be holy?
How much will this cost, guru?
How much longer till you completely absolve me?
[Verse 2]
I've seen them give their drugs up in place of makeshift altars
I've heard them chanting "Kali Kali" frantically
I've heard them rotely repeat your teachings with elitism
I've seen them boasting robes and foreign sandalwood beads

[Chorus]
How long will this take, baba?
How long have we been sleeping?
Do you see me hanging on to every word you say?
How soon will I be holy?
How much will this cost, guru?
How much longer till you completely absolve me?

[Bridge]
Ave Maria
Ave Maria
Ave Maria
Ave Maria

[Verse 3]
I've seen men overlooking God in their own essence
I've seen their upward glances in hopes of instant salvation
I've seen their righteousness mixed without loving compassion
I've watched you smile as the students bow to kiss your feet
You might also like[Chorus]
How long will this take, baba?
How long have we been sleeping?
Do you see me hanging on to every word you say?
How soon will I be holy?
How much will this cost, guru?
How much longer till you completely absolve me?
Give me strength, all-knowing one
How long 'til enlightenment?
How much longer until you completely absolve me?

[Outro]
Ave Maria
Ave Maria
Ave Maria
Ave Maria1Embed
annotation:
[('I’ve heard them rotely repeat your teachings with elitism', [['Sathya Sai Baba was a “living god” to forty million people, and his believers have credited him with resurrecting the dead and healing the sick.']]), ('How long will this take', [['Baba had a nine-billion-dollar organization and religious centers throughout the world.']]), ('Nirvana', [['For a contrary thought on this point, go listen to and read about Van Morrison’s “Precious Time”.']]), ('Ave Maria
 Ave Maria
 Ave Maria
 Ave Maria', [['A Western, Catholic example of devotion to a spiritual master – in this case, the Virgin Mary … perhaps Morissette is suggesting devotion can be genuine or counterfeit in any religious tradition?']]), ('I’ve watched you smile as the students bow to kiss your feet', [['And maybe this isn’t only an ego trip for the supplicants … The guru smiles as they kiss his feet …']]), ('Frantically', [['A play on words – “kali” and “fran-ti-cally [kali]”']]), ('Do you see me', [['I hope you see my devotion, guru – it’s all about status and getting the goodie, after all.']]), ('Pseudo higher levels', [['Not truly higher levels (dissension)']]), ('Overlooking God in their own essence', [['Now Morissette is saying what she thinks the spiritual tourists are missing. God is in their own essences; they boast righteousness but what they seek is loving compassion.']]), ('How much will this cost, guru?', [['A double-meaning – How much will it cost me, spiritually and emotionally, to learn the lessons and follow this discipline? and … How much money will it cost me to travel, stay, eat, buy the materials, and (especially) support your ministry?']])]

title: Thank U
lyrics:
Thank U Lyrics[Verse 1]
How 'bout getting off of these antibiotics
How 'bout stopping eating when I'm full up
How 'bout them transparent dangling carrots
How 'bout that ever elusive kudo

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence
[Verse 2]
How 'bout me not blaming you for everything
How 'bout me enjoying the moment for once
How 'bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
How 'bout grieving it all one at a time

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence

[Bridge]
The moment I let go of it
Was the moment I got more than I could handle
The moment I jumped off of it
Was the moment I touched down

[Verse 3]
How 'bout no longer being masochistic
How 'bout remembering your divinity
How 'bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
How 'bout not equating death with stopping
You might also like[Chorus 2]
Thank you India
Thank you providence
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you nothingness
Thank you clarity
Thank you, thank you silence

[Outro]
Yeah, yeah
Oh, oh, oh-oh
No, oh, oh, oh
No, oh, oh, oh12Embed
annotation:
[('Thank you India', [['In between Jagged Little Pill and Supposed former infatuation junkie. Alanis took a break and traveled to India. This song is a reflection of her trip.']]), ('How ’bout no longer being masochistic
 How ’bout remembering your divinity
 How ’bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
 How ’bout not equating death with stopping', [["Again, the core of the song’s message, here we see a side that’s a tad darker. We are told to love ourselves and not be masochistic. “Remembering our divinity” is most likely about faith in embetterment, and that we can change if we believe enough.
Crying is, to most people, a very cathartic process and helps them get over the sadness and anger that they feel and reach a more serene state of mind. Alanis feels that we should be able to do so unapologetically.

The line about “not equating death with stopping” stems from one of Alanis' interviews. She said that when the tour for Jagged Little Pill was over, she finally sat in her room, doing nothing and she said she felt like she was dead, but a good kind of death. She now believes that we should not feel dead if we stop doing something that exhausts us, and that we should be thankful: firstly, for being able to do that thing in the first place; and secondly that we were able to stop."]]), ('How ’bout me not blaming you for everything
 How ’bout me enjoying the moment for once
 How ’bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
 How ’bout grieving it all one at a time', [['The whole song is a rumination of what we can and should do to better ourselves, and this is the core message of it. How about instead of blaming each others, we forgive, we enjoy life and all it has to offer. Sure, it won’t all be rainbows and butterflies, but living in the moment, not in the “what ifs” and “could’ve”, and just take life as it comes at us.']]), ('Thank you terror
 Thank you disillusionment
 Thank you frailty
 Thank you consequence
 Thank you, thank you silence', [['Here, Alanis acknowledges that everything that is a part of our lives helps us grow. A sort of a countinuation of “You Learn”’s theme, she thanks everything that made her the person she is today, while most people tend to dread these sorts of feelings.']]), ('How ’bout stopping eating when I’m full up
 How ’bout them transparent dangling carrots
 How ’bout that ever elusive kudo', [['Alanis muses over failings that people from western civilizations, and by extension, she herself, feels trapped in and that hat her mystical wanderings have brought to her attention, enabling her to begin to fix them.

We tend to “eat even when we’re full”, meaning that we love excesses, we love having a goal, and punishing ourselves over the things we “could have”. This is a very odd approach for what everyone pigeonholed Alanis to be: an angry woman, and it is a much more serene approach to life.']]), ('The moment I let go of it
 Was the moment I got more than I could handle
 The moment I jumped off of it
 Was the moment I touched down', [['Here the author realizes that she was trying to carry more she was able to.
When she let it go she could see it from a different perspective.']])]

title: Are You Still Mad
lyrics:
Are You Still Mad Lyrics[Verse 1]
Are you still mad I kicked you out of bed?
Are you still mad I gave you ultimatums?
Are you still mad I compared you to all my forty year old male friends?
Are you still mad I shared our problems with everybody?
Are you still mad I had an emotional affair?
Are you still mad I tried to mold you into who I wanted you to be?
Are you still mad I didn't trust your intentions?

[Chorus]
Of course you are, of course you are
Of course you are, of course you are
[Verse 2]
Are you still mad that I flirted wildly?
Are you still mad I had a tendency to mother you?
Are you still mad that I had one foot out the door?
Are you still mad that we slept together even after we had ended it?

[Chorus]
Of course you are, of course you are
Of course you are, of course you are

[Verse 3]
Are you still mad I wore the pants most of the time?
Are you still mad that I seemed to focus only on your potential?
Are you still mad that I threw in the towel?
Are you still mad that I gave up long before you did?

[Chorus]
Of course you are, of course you are
Of course you are, of course you areYou might also like2Embed
annotation:
[('Of course you are, of course you are
 Of course you are, of course you are', [['Of course they’re still mad. Of course they didn’t want to be her plaything any longer. Of course they were disillusioned with her eagerness to leave them. Of course they’re resentful for the mindgames Alanis played.']]), ('Are you still mad that I threw in the towel?
 Are you still mad that I gave up long before you did?', [['And abandon ship she did. She says yet again that she was ready to do so for a loooooong time.']]), ('Are you still mad that I seemed to focus only on your potential?', [['This line is most probably the key to the puzzle of this relationship’s existence. While it was unclear at best in previous lines why they got together in the first place, this is the most solid explanation: Alanis saw potential husband material in him. She tries to mold him into what she saw fit to be her husband and yet was ready to abandon ship at any time. She didn’t really see him as her lover, but as more of a sentient pet. This, of course, cannot lead to happiness from either, so it’s only a matter of time before the boat starts sinking. It has been made extremely clear throughout most of the song that Alanis is more than ready to abandon ship, should the need to dos so rise.']]), ('Are you still mad I wore the pants most of the time?', [['This line is a very stark contrast to the beginning of the song. She now states that she was in charge most of the time, and that she didn’t even care up until now(when she asks but tauntingly) whether he was ok with it or not. She really shows that to her, this was just some sort of a pastime, and she wouldn’t have had this led by someone else. A very interesting perspective.']]), ('Are you still mad that I had one foot out the door?
 Are you still mad that we slept together even after we had ended it?', [['She was always ready to end this relationship. After everyhting, it becomes less and less clear why this relationship existed in the first place. It begs the question: why did Alanis agree to be in a relationship with a man she does not respect, all while being ready to leave at any moment?']]), ('Are you still mad that I flirted wildly?
 Are you still mad I had a tendency to mother you?', [['Again, this gives insight on the relationship. She did not really respect him in any way. She flirted “wildly” while they were together, and she treated him like he couldn’t handle himself. This ties in to the immaturity that she accused him of, again showing that Alanis is the one responsible for the breakup, by not having been invested in the first place. We know that she was not invested emotionally in any way, and now we know that she didn’t even try to hide it.']]), ('Of course you are, of course you are
 Of course you are, of course you are', [['The chorus really shows why the whole song is mostly a taunt. Alanis knows very well that her (supposedly former) lover would be mad about most(if not all) of these things. Despite this, she still asks and brings up all the painful memories, again and again, taunting and tormenting the person that this song is about.']]), ('Are you still mad I tried to mold you into who I wanted you to be?
 Are you still mad I didn’t trust your intentions?', [['This is where we get to see more of the insides of this relaionship. Although at first it seems that she tried to play the lamb, she is most clearly the wolf in this story. She was manipulative to the point of changing who her lover was as a person, and even moreso, she didn’t really trust them, or their intentions, showing how this love was most probably one sided.']]), ('Are you still mad I had an emotional affair?', [['This is a very interesting line, because while ambiguous, it offers a pretty good idea of what is going on. We don’t exactly know what an “emotional affair” really entails, but we can break it down and get close to an answer. First of all, we have to adress the elephant in the room, the fact that she had an affair. Most prople have affairs because they are dissatisfied with their partners. However, the wound is in this case even more grieveous, because it was not physical. While the justification of a sexual affair can be the impulse of the moment, or hormones or whatnot, this time it cannot. This affair was rational, start to finish. Again, this shows the taunting nature of the lyrics.']]), ('Are you still mad I compared you to all my forty year old male friends?
 Are you still mad I shared our problems with everybody?', [["Now, this is where we start to see what is really happening. While the previous lines wouldn’t really solicit the question of still being mad, this is where it begins. Alanis is crossing a lot of lines which she shouldn’t be, by comparing her lover to all her older friends, making him feel bad, because he isn’t as mature as a fourty year old would be. Moreover, after making him feel immature, she also shares this with said friends and more. This discredits him even more in the others' eyes, thus making Alanis' lover doubt himself even more and think less and less of himself."]])]

title: Sympathetic Character

I was afraid of your explosions
You might also like[Pre-Chorus]
Because I have as much rage as you have

And I've kept mine bubbling under for you

[Chorus]
You were my best friend
You were my lover
You were my mentor
You were my brother
You were my partner
You were my teacher
You were my very own sympathetic character

[Instrumental Bridge]

[Chorus]
You were my best friend
You were my lover
You were my mentor
You were my brother
You were my partner
You were my teacher
You were my very own sympathetic character

[Outro]
And therein lay the issue

And therein lay the issue

annotation:
[('Because I have as much rage as you have
 I have as much pain as you do
 I’ve lived as much hell as you have
 And I’ve kept mine bubbling under for you', [['She’s highlighting and justifying the “sympathetic character” that she understands to live within herself as she’s the true victim in this abusive relationship. It’s meant to stand in stark comparison to her abuser, who is also sometimes seen as a “sympathetic character”, in her eyes, when it serves him in gaslighting her. She’s acknowledging her rage and subsequent pain in a moment of vulnerability (which is, psychologically, a power move) before warning she too possesses a similar ability to be the monster he is, towards him, perhaps even worse, yet she actively chooses not to be what she fears, because she knows first hand she’s not less than him. She can control herself. He can’t.']]), ('I was afraid of verbal daggers
 I was afraid of the calm before the storm
 I was afraid for my own bones
 I was afraid of your seduction
 I was afraid of your coercion
 I was afraid of your rejection
 I was afraid of your intimidation
 I was afraid of your punishment
 I was afraid of your icy silences
 I was afraid of your volume
 I was afraid of your manipulation
 I was afraid of your explosions', [['This is what being gaslit feels like. All of it']]), ('Sympathetic character', [['A sympathetic character is one that evokes empathy in the reader. This character might function as a self-insert, or framing for the whole story.']]), ('Testosterone', [['Testosterone, a hormone associated with male-type sexual distinction, is sometimes blamed for causing violent behavior or increasing aggression.']])]

title: That I Would Be Good
lyrics:
That I Would Be Good Lyrics[Verse 1]
That I would be good even if I did nothing
That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down
That I would be good if I got and stayed sick
That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds
That I would be fine even if I went bankrupt
That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth
That I would be great if I was no longer queen
That I would be grand if I was not all knowing

[Chorus]
That I would be loved even when I numb myself
That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
That I would be loved even when I was fuming
That I would be good even if I was clingy
[Verse 2]
That I would be good even if I lost sanity
That I would be good whether with or without you

[Outro]
I, I would
I, IYou might also like2Embed
annotation:
[('That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth', [['Many critics of Morissette’s blockbuster first album were frequently impressed at the startling maturity, insight, and honesty of her lyrics from such a young songwriter, which might well have caused her to wonder if they’d find her as impressive in a few years, when she seemed less a prodigy.']]), ('That I would be loved even when I numb myself
 That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
 That I would be loved even when I was fuming
 That I would be good even if I was clingy', [["The song acts as a sort of prayer or mantra that Alanis feels represents her current state, as of writing the album. While it may seem downbeat and sad, the song stems from a place of hope and vulnerability. The absence of the predicate leaves the song open to interpretation. The general vibe of the song begs for something along the lines of “I pray” or “I hope”, however it is up to the listener entirely.  Probably one of Alanis' most heartfelt."]]), ('That I would be grand if I was not all knowing', [['I think this is a wink to religion, or religous people. God can be viewed  upon as all-knowing. Here, the word ‘grand’ is used as superlative to good and great and is not surpassed in these lyrics, thus being the highest possible.

So the line states ‘being not surpassed, but not all-knowing’. This hints at a God that might not be all-knowing, but still the grandest power we know.

It subtly says that even the highest power might have a blind spot and that being ‘good’, ‘great’ or ‘grand’ remains relative and subjective.']]), ('That I would be good if I got and stayed sick', [['One of the most sensitive, delicate lines in this song, referring to being incurable ill. Some views hold that being in this condition is something one has called upon itself due to bad lifestyle for example.
Others view that the acceptance of having an incurable disease is the same as giving up the fight, to resign. People are expected to ‘fight’ diseases like cancer to the end. Alanis here asks herself is this is the only way to be viewed as ‘good’.

Alanis emphasizes here that having an incurable disease and accepting it, might be a good thing.']]), ('That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds', [['Since appearance is an important thing in western culture and gaining weight is often considered a bad thing, Alanis refers to the issues surrounding weight gain that could bring people to adapt their eating pattern/lifestyle into something they do, not because they want to, but because others want them to.']]), ('That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down', [['Again, referring to the pressure others can put onto you by expressing their view/opinion.
Alanis refers to critics who would give a thumb down to something she created with passion and love. She’s not into music to create crappy songs, still it might not please everyone, especially those who think they know what she should sing/write/produce.']]), ('That I would be good even if I did nothing', [['The opening line of the song refers to the pressure western culture brings to its people. We are expected constantly be doing things, being busy.
Doing nothing is not considered  a virtue in western culture, but it really can strain people.
Alanis kicks off with this line, because after the success of “Jagged Little Pill”, people were constantly breathing down her neck for new material, which she could only produce after taking a long time off.']])]

title: The Couch
lyrics:
The Couch Lyrics[Verse]
You hadn't seen your father in such a long time
He died in the arms of his lover, how dare he
Your mother never left the house
She never married anyone else
You took it upon yourself to console her
You reminded her so much of your father
So you were banished and you
Wonder why you're so hypersensitive
And why you can't trust anyone but us
But then how can I begin to forgive her?
So many years under bridges with dirty water
She was foolish and selfish
And cowardly, if you ask me
I don't know where to begin
In all of my 50 odd years
I have been silently suffering and adapting perpetuating and enduring
Who are you younger generation to tell me
That I have unresolved problems?
Not many examples of fruits
Of this type of excruciating labor
How can you just throw words around?
Like grieve and heal and mourn
I feel fine we may not have been born
As awake as you were
It was much harder in those days
We had paper routes uphill both ways
We went from school to a job to a wife
To instant parenthood
I walked into his office
I felt so self-conscious on the couch
He was sitting down across from me
He was writing down his hypothesis, I don't know
I've got a loving supportive wife
Who doesn't know how involved she should get
You say his interjecting was him just calling me on my shit
Just the other day, my sweet daughter
I was driving past 203
I walked up the stairs in my mind's eye
I remember how they would creak loudly
She was only responsive with a drink
He was only responsive by photo
I was only trying to be the best big brother I could
I've walked sometimes confused
Sometimes ready to crack open wide
Sometimes indignant, sometimes raw
Can you imagine I pay him 75 dollars an hour?
Sometimes it feels like highway robbery
And sometimes it's peanuts
I wish it could last a couple more hours
So here we both are battling similar demons
Not coincidentally
You see, in getting beyond knowing it solely intellectually
You're not relinquishing your majesty
You are wise, you are warm
You are courageous, you are big
And I love you more now than I ever have in my whole lifeYou might also like1Embed
annotation:
[('How can you just throw words around?
 Like grieve and heal and mourn
 I feel fine we may not have been born
 As awake as you were
 It was much harder in those days
 We had paper routes uphill both ways
 We went from school to a job to a wife
 To instant parenthood', [['A continuation of the previous verse; he is feeling defensive and perhaps experiencing cognitive dissonance re: his conflicting feelings towards his mother. On the one hand, he is able to clearly verbalize the  contempt/resentment he has towards her; on the other, he is still the young, sad and hurt child rejected by the one person who was supposed to love him unconditionally. He spent years trying to fix her (likely by attempting to “love her move”) to no avail. The simultaneous existence of unrequited love / resulting emotional pain and 50 years of pent up anger are creating an inner conflict that he perhaps isn’t consciously aware of yet, and likely the root of his vacillating positive and negative attitudes towards his treatment. To a much lesser degree of severity, he is projecting his relationship with his mother onto the therapist (a standard part of the therapeutic process) in order to try to find a way to cope & move past it.

Re: the actual lyrics (lol), he is mildly insulting the therapist and/or his daughter by implying that although they toss around psychological terms (grieve, heal, mourn); they are essentially meaningless because in his mind “it’s not that easy”…at least not in the age he grew up in, where there wasn’t time for such “indulgences.” He also makes a slightly sideways sarcastic remark that “[he] might not have been born as wide awake as [they] were.”']]), ('I have been silently suffering and adapting perpetuating and enduring
 Who are you younger generation to tell me
 That I have unresolved problems?
 Not many examples of fruits
 Of this type of excruciating labor', [['The patient is an old man that noe ges angry at the, presumably younger, psychologist. He is told that he has a lot of issues, a fact which, while true, is unpleasant to him. He is proud that he made it despite not having any kind of support, and considers that the psychologist has no right whatsoever to point out any of his faults.']]), ('So here we both are battling similar demons
 Not coincidentally
 You see, in getting beyond knowing it solely intellectually
 You’re not relinquishing your majesty
 You are wise, you are warm
 You are courageous, you are big
 And I love you more now than I ever have in my whole life', [['This is either his wife or his mind as his mother, although most probably the latter. He is proud of himself for battling the demons his mother could not by seeking help. The ghost of his mothe(or the figment of his imagination) congratulates him. However, since this is probably not real, his problems are far from over…']]), ('I’ve walked sometimes confused
 Sometimes ready to crack open wide
 Sometimes indignant, sometimes raw
 Can you imagine I pay him 75 dollars an hour?
 Sometimes it feels like highway robbery
 And sometimes it’s peanuts
 I wish it could last a couple more hours', [['This is probably the patient’s rumination which he kept to himself. He thinks of the array of emotions these sessions cause him. Sometimes, he is angry and feels they are pointless and a waste of money, however, being the one person that actually listens, he wishes sometimes that they would actually last more, since all the emotions he’s had inside’ve built up, almost making him snap.']]), ('Just the other day, my sweet daughter
 I was driving past 203
 I walked up the stairs in my mind’s eye
 I remember how they would creak loudly
 She was only responsive with a drink
 He was only responsive by photo
 I was only trying to be the best big brother I could', [["Here, the patient remembers walking by his parents' house. His mother is now an alcoholic and his little brother is dead, which makes him imagine how he would meet them inside. Now, he feels somewhat guilty, trying to justify his actions in front of the doctor."]]), ('I walked into his office
 I felt so self-conscious on the couch
 He was sitting down across from me
 He was writing down his hypothesis, I don’t know
 I’ve got a loving supportive wife
 Who doesn’t know how involved she should get
 You say his interjecting was him just calling me on my shit', [['In contrast to the previous verses, this is the first time in the song that the patient feels something other than anger. Here, he feels that on the psychologist’s couch he is vulnerable, because they are being probed and questioned and it makes them uncomfortable. He mentions his wife for the first time, and he now realizes the graviti of his predicament, thinking that his wife should be more involved in this. He feels that any slight gesture or sound made by the psychologist is threatening or chastising.']]), ('You reminded her so much of your father
 So you were banished and you
 Wonder why you’re so hypersensitive
 And why you can’t trust anyone but us
 But then how can I begin to forgive her?
 So many years under bridges with dirty water
 She was foolish and selfish
 And cowardly, if you ask me
 I don’t know where to begin
 In all of my 50 odd years', [['This is the patient talking. He is having a bout of rage because he is reminescing about all the hardships he endured because of his mother. She was so pained by her husband’s affair AND passing that she tried to eliminate the memory of this traumatic event. Yet, one thing stopped her: her son’s resemblance to him. She hated her husband so much for cheating on her that she banished her son, leaving him to wander the streets and fend for himself. He is very resentful for this, because he had to struggle very much, having no financial support. Moreover, his mother would rather be alone than remember her husband which is, truly, foolish and cowardly.']]), ('You hadn’t seen your father in such a long time
 He died in the arms of his lover, how dare he
 Your mother never left the house
 She never married anyone else
 You took it upon yourself to console her', [['This song is a dialogue between the psychologist and a schizophrenic patient. At first, the psychologist is stating some facts about the patient’s life, most probably told in another session, which trigger an episode. This first verse showcases the root of all their patient’s problems: a very troubled family life. They come from a broken home and a depressive mother.']])]

title: Can't Not
lyrics:
Can’t Not Lyrics[Verse 1]

title: I Was Hoping
lyrics:
I Was Hoping Lyrics[Verse 1]
As we were talking outside, it was cold
We were shivering, yet warmed by the subject matter
“My wife is in the next room
We’ve been having troubles, you know
Please, don’t tell her or anyone, but I need to talk to somebody”
You said, “Wouldn’t it be a shame if I knew how great I was five minutes before I died?
I’d be filled with such regret before I took my last breath”
And I said, “You’re willing to tell me this now, and you’re not gonna to die any time soon”
And I said, “I haven’t been eating chicken or meat or anything”
And you said, “Yes, but you’ve been wearing leather”, and laughed and said, “We’re at the top of the food chain, and yes, you’re still a fine woman”
I cringed
[Chorus 1]
I was hoping, I was hoping we could heal each other
I was hoping, I was hoping we could be raw together

[Verse 2]
We left the restaurant where the head waiter, in his 60s, said “Goodbye, sir
Thank you for your business, sir
You’re successful and established, sir
And we like the frequency with which you dine here, sir… and your money”
And when I walked by, they said, “Thank you too, dear”
I was all pigtails and cords, and there was a day when I would’ve said something like, “Hey, dude, I could buy and sell this place, so kiss it”
I too once thought I was owed something

[Chorus 2]
I was hoping, I was hoping we could challenge each other
I was hoping, I was hoping we could crack each other up

[Verse 3]
I too thought that, when proved wrong, I lost somehow
And I too once thought life was cruel, and it’s a cycle, really
You think I’m withdrawing and guilt-tripping you
I think you’re insensitive, and I don’t feel heard
And I said, “Do you believe we are fundamentally judgmental, fundamentally evil?”, and you said, “Yes”
I said, “I don’t believe in revenge, in right or wrong, good or bad”
You said, “Well, what about that man that I saw handcuffed in the emergency room, bleeding after beating his kid, and she threw a shoe at his head? I think what he did was wrong and I would’ve had a hard time feeling compassion for him”
I had to watch my tone for fear of having you feel judged
You might also like[Chorus 3]
I was hoping, I was hoping we could dance together
I was hoping, I was hoping we could be creamy together1Embed
annotation:
[('“My wife is in the next room
 We’ve been having troubles, you know
 Please, don’t tell her or anyone, but I need to talk to somebody”', [['The man she is having an affair with is having mental health troubles because of his loveless marriage. He can’t confide in his own wife, and has to date another woman in order to talk to someone about his health.']]), ('“Goodbye, sir
 Thank you for your business, sir
 You’re successful and established, sir
 And we like the frequency with which you dine here, sir… and your money”', [['The waiter, of course, didn’t really say all this aloud, but the singer senses in the deference the waiter gives to her male friend that he is subtly acknowledging his privileges, as opposed to the condescension with which the waiter treats the singer by acknowledging her as an afterthought and calling her “dear,” unaware that the singer herself is equally successful, established, and rich.']])]

annotation: [('I have abused my so-called power, forgive me\n You mean we actually are all one\n One, one, one, one, one, one, one', [['She now prays to god for his acceptance in her apology.']]), ('I’ve gotten candy for my self-interest', [['She might be referencing the dentists in this line, Because at the dentist’s, they’ll give you a piece of candy (mainly a lollypop) once they looked at your teeth if you were a child.']])]

So Pure Lyrics[Verse 1]

When you freestyle in trance

annotation: [('I love you when you dance\n When you freestyle in trance\n So pure, such an expression', [['This song could almost be the opposite of “I Was Hoping.” In “I Was Hoping,” Morissette expresses frustration at a friend tangled up in overly deep moral struggling when what she needs is to get out of her own head. In this song, the subject is fully alive in the moment and she admires him for his enjoyment and optimism.']])]

title: Joining You
lyrics:
Joining You Lyrics[Verse 1]
Dear darlin', your mom, my friend
Left a message on my machine
She was frantic, saying you were talking crazy
That you wanted to do away with yourself
Guess she thought I would be the perfect resort
'Cause we've had this inexplicable connection since our youth
And yes, they're in shock, they are panicked
You and your chronic, them and their drama
You, this embarrassment
Us in the middle of this delusion
[Chorus]
If we were our bodies
If we were our futures
If we were our defenses
I'd be joining you
If we were our culture
If we were our leaders
If we were our denials
I'd be joining you

[Verse 2]
I remember vividly a day years ago
We were camping
You knew more than you thought you should know
You said I don't want ever to be brainwashed
And you were mind-boggling, you were intense
You were uncomfortable in your own skin
You were thirsty
But mostly, you were beautiful

[Chorus]
If we were our name tags
If we were our rejections
If we were our outcomes
I'd be joining you
If we were our indignities
If we were our successes
If we were our emotions
I'd be joining you
You might also like[Verse 3]
You and I, we're like four-year-olds
We want to know why and how come about everything
We want to reveal ourselves at will and speak our minds
And never talk small and be intuitive
And question mightily and find God
My tortured beacon
We need to find like-minded companions

[Chorus]
If we were their condemnations
If we were their projections
If we were our paranoias
I'd be joining you
If we were our incomes
If we were our obsessions
If we were our afflictions
I'd be joining you

[Outro]
We need reflection
We need a really good memory
Feel free to call me a little more often7Embed
annotation:
[('And yes, they’re in shock, they are panicked', [['the wish of the friend to end their life has come as a shock to everyone around them.']]), ('Dear darlin’, your mom, my friend
 Left a message on my machine
 She was frantic, saying you were talking crazy
 That you wanted to do away with yourself
 Guess she thought I would be the perfect resort
 ’Cause we’ve had this inexplicable connection since our youth', [['A friend’s mother called Alanis in hopes that she could talk some sense into her daughter who was obviously feeling at the end of her rope with life.']]), ('If we were our bodies
 If we were our futures
 If we were our defenses
 I’d be joining you
 If we were our culture
 If we were our leaders
 If we were our denials
 I’d be joining you', [['The chorus is repeated three times throughout the song and each time she lists things that belong to the material world — such as body, success, emotions, culture, leaders etc, but since we are greater than those things, Alanis tries to convince her friend to not commit a suicide.

She doesn’t specifically says what we are, since it goes beyond human physical experiences and definitions.

So, she’s saying if we were merely those earthly things, she’ll joining you and commit a suicide too, but we’re more than that, don’t do it.']])]

title: Heart of the House
lyrics:
Heart of the House Lyrics[Verse 1]
You are the original template

You loved us more than we could've loved you back

[Refrain]

The heart of the house
The heart of the house
All hail the Goddess
[Verse 2]
You were good old

You saw me run from the house
In the snow melodramatically

[Refrain]

The heart of the house
The heart of that house
All hail the Goddess

[Verse 3]
We left the men and we went for a walk in the Gatineaus
And talked like women, like women to women would
Women to women would
Where did you get that from?

Do you see yourself in my gypsy garage sale ways?

annotation:
[('We left the men and we went for a walk in the Gatineaus
 And talked like women, like women to women would
 Women to women would', [['Referencing a time when Alanis was able to walk and talk with her mother like women or friends rather than as mother to daughter.']]), ('Where did you get that from?
 Must’ve been your father, your dad
 I got it from you, I got it from you
 Do you see yourself in my gypsy garage sale ways?
 In my fits of laughter
 In my Tinkerbell tendencies
 In my lack of color coordination', [["Alanis is saying that maybe her mother was doing so much “mothering” that she is not even aware that some of Alanis' qualities come directly from her."]]), ('You are the original template
 You are the original exemplary
 How seen were you actually?
 How revered were you, honestly, at the time?
 Why, pleased with your low maintenance
 You loved us more than we could’ve loved you back
 Where was your ally, your partner in feminine crime?', [['Alanis is saying that her mother is the first person in her life to really make an impact and that all the great things her mother was doing for her were going relatively unnoticed. Her mother was doing everything out of the love that only a mother can provide.']])]

title: Joining You

Joining You Lyrics[Verse 1]
Dear darlin', your mom, my friend

Us in the middle of this delusion

I'd be joining you

We want to know why and how come about everything
We want to reveal ourselves at will and speak our minds
And never talk small and be intuitive
And question mightily and find God
My tortured beacon
We need to find like-minded companions

[Chorus]

If we were their projections

I'd be joining you

If we were our obsessions
If we were our afflictions

[Outro]
We need reflection

Feel free to call me a little more often7Embed
annotation:
[('And yes, they’re in shock, they are panicked', [['the wish of the friend to end their life has come as a shock to everyone around them.']]), ('Dear darlin’, your mom, my friend
 Left a message on my machine
 She was frantic, saying you were talking crazy
 That you wanted to do away with yourself
 Guess she thought I would be the perfect resort
 ’Cause we’ve had this inexplicable connection since our youth', [['A friend’s mother called Alanis in hopes that she could talk some sense into her daughter who was obviously feeling at the end of her rope with life.']]), ('If we were our bodies
 If we were our futures
 If we were our defenses
 I’d be joining you
 If we were our culture
 If we were our leaders
 If we were our denials
 I’d be joining you', [['The chorus is repeated three times throughout the song and each time she lists things that belong to the material world — such as body, success, emotions, culture, leaders etc, but since we are greater than those things, Alanis tries to convince her friend to not commit a suicide.

She doesn’t specifically says what we are, since it goes beyond human physical experiences and definitions.

So, she’s saying if we were merely those earthly things, she’ll joining you and commit a suicide too, but we’re more than that, don’t do it.']])]

title: That I Would Be Good
lyrics:
That I Would Be Good Lyrics[Verse 1]
That I would be good even if I did nothing
That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down
That I would be good if I got and stayed sick
That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds
That I would be fine even if I went bankrupt
That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth
That I would be great if I was no longer queen
That I would be grand if I was not all knowing

[Chorus]
That I would be loved even when I numb myself
That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
That I would be loved even when I was fuming
That I would be good even if I was clingy
[Verse 2]
That I would be good even if I lost sanity
That I would be good whether with or without you

[Outro]
I, I would
I, IYou might also like2Embed
annotation:
[('That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth', [['Many critics of Morissette’s blockbuster first album were frequently impressed at the startling maturity, insight, and honesty of her lyrics from such a young songwriter, which might well have caused her to wonder if they’d find her as impressive in a few years, when she seemed less a prodigy.']]), ('That I would be loved even when I numb myself
 That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
 That I would be loved even when I was fuming
 That I would be good even if I was clingy', [["The song acts as a sort of prayer or mantra that Alanis feels represents her current state, as of writing the album. While it may seem downbeat and sad, the song stems from a place of hope and vulnerability. The absence of the predicate leaves the song open to interpretation. The general vibe of the song begs for something along the lines of “I pray” or “I hope”, however it is up to the listener entirely.  Probably one of Alanis' most heartfelt."]]), ('That I would be grand if I was not all knowing', [['I think this is a wink to religion, or religous people. God can be viewed  upon as all-knowing. Here, the word ‘grand’ is used as superlative to good and great and is not surpassed in these lyrics, thus being the highest possible.

So the line states ‘being not surpassed, but not all-knowing’. This hints at a God that might not be all-knowing, but still the grandest power we know.

It subtly says that even the highest power might have a blind spot and that being ‘good’, ‘great’ or ‘grand’ remains relative and subjective.']]), ('That I would be good if I got and stayed sick', [['One of the most sensitive, delicate lines in this song, referring to being incurable ill. Some views hold that being in this condition is something one has called upon itself due to bad lifestyle for example.
Others view that the acceptance of having an incurable disease is the same as giving up the fight, to resign. People are expected to ‘fight’ diseases like cancer to the end. Alanis here asks herself is this is the only way to be viewed as ‘good’.

Alanis emphasizes here that having an incurable disease and accepting it, might be a good thing.']]), ('That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds', [['Since appearance is an important thing in western culture and gaining weight is often considered a bad thing, Alanis refers to the issues surrounding weight gain that could bring people to adapt their eating pattern/lifestyle into something they do, not because they want to, but because others want them to.']]), ('That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down', [['Again, referring to the pressure others can put onto you by expressing their view/opinion.
Alanis refers to critics who would give a thumb down to something she created with passion and love. She’s not into music to create crappy songs, still it might not please everyone, especially those who think they know what she should sing/write/produce.']]), ('That I would be good even if I did nothing', [['The opening line of the song refers to the pressure western culture brings to its people. We are expected constantly be doing things, being busy.
Doing nothing is not considered  a virtue in western culture, but it really can strain people.
Alanis kicks off with this line, because after the success of “Jagged Little Pill”, people were constantly breathing down her neck for new material, which she could only produce after taking a long time off.']])]

title: Head over Feet
lyrics:
Head Over Feet Lyrics[Verse 1]
I had no choice but to hear you

[Verse 2]

Than I gave you credit for

[Chorus]

In spite of me
And don't be alarmed if I fall
Head over feet
And don't be surprised if I love you
For all that you are
I couldn't help it
It's all your fault

[Verse 3]

Of unconditional things
You held your breath
And the door for me
Thanks for your patience

[Instrumental Bridge]
You might also like[Verse 4]
You're the best listener
That I've ever met
You're my best friend
Best friend with benefits
What took me so long?
I've never felt this healthy before
I've never wanted something rational
I am aware now, oh
I am aware now

[Chorus]
You've already won me over
In spite of me
And don't be alarmed if I fall
Head over feet
And don't be surprised if I love you
For all that you are
I couldn't help it
It's all your fault

[Chorus]
You've already won me over
In spite of me
And don't be alarmed if I fall
Head over feet
And don't be surprised if I love you
For all that you are
I couldn't help it
It's all your fault
[Outro]
I couldn't help it
It's all your fault14Embed
annotation:
[('It’s all your fault', [['Another playful reversal. She’s lovingly teasing him as her way of thanking him. Obviously, he’s done nothing wrong—she’s not faulting him at all!']]), ('Head over feet', [['The main message of the song is about reversals, inversions, flipping the script to something unexpected: The title is a playful tweak of the idiom “head over heels,” which refers to being in love and “most likely developed from the literal meaning of falling upside down, as a way to describe the tumultuous emotions one feels while falling in love.”
https://writingexplained.org/idiom-dictionary/head-over-heels

Being in love is, from the perspective of the idiom, all about feeling turned upside down. It’s essentially about being surprised.

And yet the speaker tells her lover, “don’t be surprised.” (The effort to literally negate the surprise is itself another inversion!) Surprised about what? If she falls. Falls for him—in the typical somersault of giddy love described above? Not exactly. That kind of falling wouldn’t be surprising. Instead, she surprises him (and us) by tweaking the idiom:

While she doesn’t reverse the  imagery, she still manipulates the idiom away from what we expected. We expect to hear her say “head over heels,” but she surprises us—just as her experience of love has surprised her. For me, the imagery of “head over feet"—since it’s unfamiliar and thus doesn’t automatically evoke the same meaning as "head over heels"—seems less tumultuous than the original idiom suggests. Its plain meaning (while actually not really, on the surface, any different from the idiom that uses "heels”) seems to suggest the normal way we stand upright: our head is over our feet—the usual picture of standing “rightside up.” It’s actually about being grounded, standing tall (“feet planted firmly on the ground”), having a solid foundation for growth, for upward movement instead of chaotic tumbling—"ascending in love" as opposed to “falling in love.” So, while she says “don’t be surprised if I fall…”, she then, essentially, says that what will be surprising here will be the nature of the falling. It’ll be different—just like everything else in this relationship has been for her.']]), ('You’re my best friend
 Best friend with benefits', [['Believe it or not, this line is the origin of the infamous phrase that has made its way into the mainstream western vernacular, describing a relationship between two people that is sexual but not inherently long-term or romantic.']]), ('Your love is thick
 And it swallowed me whole
 You’re so much braver
 Than I gave you credit for
 That’s not lip service', [['talking about blowjobs folks!']]), ('You held your breath
 And the door for me', [['This is an example of zeugma. “Held” has a double meaning, one literal (“held the door”) and one metaphorical (“held your breath”).']])]
