annotation:
[('Enough about me, let’s talk about you for a minute
 Enough about you, let’s talk about life for a while', [["As previously seen in the song, Alanis' partner is highly critical of her, and does not shy from disappointment. To combat this, she turns the subject onto her partner, but soon becomes irritated by the very subject of them. Talking about each other becomes this vicious cycle of not wanting to be criticized turning into not wanting to hear anything about this person she shares her life with."]]), ('Slap me with the splintered ruler', [['A once common practice in classrooms a few decades ago, rapping someone’s knuckles with a ruler was done to swiftly punish students by inflicting pain as a deterrent to future bad behavior. Alanis brings forth a teacher/student dynamic in this relationship, suggesting there is a power struggle that she breaks by rebelling.

But that’s not the end. The ruler has splinters, so the criticisms of her partner have a lasting pain that gets stuck under her skin.']]), ('My sweater is on backwards and inside out
 And you say, “How appropriate!”', [['“We wrote this song in January of 1995, she walked into the studio that day, a little wan from her cold blue Canadian Christmas. And she had her sweater on backwards and turned inside-out. I pointed this out to her and she began writing the song.”
-Glen Ballard on Jagged Little Pill (Spotify Landmark Edition)']]), ('If only I could kill the killer', [["Obviously this reflects her general desire for karmic justice, but it is also connected to the previous line about time.

Time is ‘the killer’ (in Verse 3 she has already encouraged introspection about inevitable death) and to ‘kill time' has two alternate meanings: to defeat it or to spend it freely knowing that it will soon run out.

The line can be read as either ‘If only I could defeat death' or ‘If only I was able to spend my limited life freely without worrying about the future’ and both were probably intended."]]), ('I don’t wanna dissect everything today
 I don’t mean to pick you apart, you see
 But I can’t help it', [['To pick someone apart means that you try to understand them intimately, what makes them tick.

The person she’s talking to probably isn’t very deep, OR would rather discuss superficialities; they don’t like being ‘probed’ as some people call it.

These couple lines are debatably a euphemism for, how you’d say, ‘a shallow person’ (possibly, some people just aren’t comfortable discussing their personal life).

But even though they’ve already probably stated the fact that they don’t like being probed, she does it again, but comments ‘I can’t help it’. She has to know people on a deeper level.']]), ('And there I go jumping before the gunshot has gone off', [["She preemptively comes to conclusions. Perhaps because his (whom she’s addressing) behavior is so simple and predictable.

Notably, if someone jumps the starter gun, they’re liable to be disqualified from a race. Anything Alanis has to say, valid or not, is now invalidated (disqualified) from the conversation with this other person.
He ain’t gon' hear it."]]), ('Why are you so petrified of silence?
 Here, can you handle this?
 Did you think about your bills, your ex, your deadlines
 Or when you think you’re gonna die?
 Or did you long for the next distraction?', [["This is one of Alanis' most brilliant lyrics, in my opinion.  Fear of silence, or of calm, is incredibly common, and only becomes more common as we continue to surround ourselves with more and more devices to keep us “connected”.
One of the most prevalent ways this fear is manifested is having to sleep with the television/radio on.  Also, feeling the need to keep a television/radio/music on for background noise at all times, by default.  The individual becomes so accustomed to being able to focus their attention on external factors that the concept of actually focusing on their own life (such matters as their bills, exes, deadlines, impending certain death, etc…) is something they begin to avoid and eventually dread.  In a world where it is possible to be “tuned in” absolutely everywhere, many people choose to eliminate silence from their daily lives altogether, and with it, the potential for unwanted self-reflection."]]), ('And what I wouldn’t give to meet a kindred', [['Kindred has two possible meanings.


A kindred soul, continuing the sentiment expressed in the 2 previous lines.
A kindred is another term for a vampire.']]), ('I’m like Estella
 I like to reel it in and then spit it out', [['This line refers to Estella Havisham, a primary character from the novel “Great Expectations,” by Charles Dickens.  Estella is the love interest of Pip, the novel’s protagonist. While she is beautiful, refined, and intelligent, she is incapable of reciprocating any of the love Pip offers her.  Her adoptive mother, Miss Havisham, holds a passionate hatred toward all men, and made it a point to impart the same values on Estella as she raised her.  As a result, the ability to love a man has been destroyed for Estella.  I believe that the aspect of the character in particular that Alanis resembles in this song is the effect Estella has on men.  How despite having made it clear that she would never feel anything for Pip, he does not give up.  I think Alanis is alluding to the fact that Estella has the power to make this man (men in general) love her without ever doing anything to deserve or earn it, and what that quality/power can be used for when harnessed.']])]

title: Precious Illusions
lyrics:
Precious Illusions Lyrics[Verse 1]
You'll rescue me, right?
In the exact same way they never did
I'll be happy, right?
When your healing powers kick in
You'll complete me, right?
Then my life can finally begin
I'll be worthy, right?
Only when you realize the gem I am

[Pre-Chorus 1]
But this won't work now the way it once did
And I won't keep it up even though I would love to
Once I know who I'm not then I'll know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim
[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends

[Verse 2]
This ring will help me yet
As will you, knight in shining armor
This pill will help me yet
As will these boys gone through like water

[Pre-Chorus 2]
But this won't work as well as the way it once did
Because I want to decide between survival and bliss
And though I know who I'm not I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend

[Bridge]
I've spent so long firmly looking outside me
I've spent so much time living in survival mode
You might also like[Pre-Chorus 3]
This won't work now the way it once did
'Cause I want to decide between survival and bliss
Now I know who I'm not, I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend2Embed
annotation:
[('This ring will help me yet
 As will you, knight in shining armor
 This pill will help me yet
 As will these boys gone through like water', [['In this verse, Alanis catalogs the different ways she can “fix” herself: getting married, finding the right guy, taking drugs, sleeping with lots of guys. None of them work, obviously.']]), ('Survival and bliss', [['Alanis is obviously looking at the thought-patterns in her psyche that are ego-based, which are also survival-based (survival of the ego, of the identity). I imagine she is recognizing that these sub-conscious patterns have limited her experience of life. And here, she is seeking bliss instead.

Philosophically speaking, ‘bliss’ is not the only word that fits here. We could insert ‘truth’, ‘freedom’, ‘peace’, or ‘joy’ here as well.']]), ('These precious illusions in my head
 Did not let me down when I was defenseless
 And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends', [["Alanis' precious illusion – which is a pretty common illusion, especially in early age – was that she might one day find someone who give her a reason to be. In the second verse she also implies that she used to find solace and hope in material things, like the “magical pill” that could solve all her problems.

However, these illusions were her “best friend” when she was “a kid”, which could also metaphorically allude to a person who was new to life and still had a lot to learn. Now that she’s acknowledged that these thoughts don’t work in real life and aren’t going to sustain her any longer she can’t just pretend, she has to get rid of them."]]), ('But I know I won’t keep on playing the victim', [['It’s so easy to pass responsibility onto everyone else and this is a great strategy of the ego. As soon as Alanis acknowledges that she can’t rely on someone else to feel as a whole, to mend herself and to finally begin her life, she decides to take all the responsibility of what she will go through.

She may not know who she is yet, but at least she realized that it doesn’t matter as long as she might find it out by herself in the future and in the meantime she’s living like there’s no tomorrow.']]), ('Once I know who I’m not then I’ll know who I am', [['‘Who am I?’ always has been and always will be the ultimate question. Great philosophers for millennia have asked it, and most have great difficulty answering it.

Alanis appears to have chosen to use the strategy of deduction: if I’m not ready to answer ‘Who am I?’, then I may answer ‘Who am I not?’ And of course this is a work in progress. Psychologists often use the ‘onion analogy’, whereby one must peel away layer by layer by layer to get to the center of one’s psyche.']]), ('But this won’t work now the way it once did
 And I won’t keep it up even though I would love to', [['Once Alanis found out that these thoughts aren’t going to bring her comfort any longer, she just decides to drop them and find the truth in something else.

There comes a point in one’s journey, often times at a low point, when a soul realizes that all her strategies for happiness and wholeness simply have not served her. This can be very scary as humans tend to depend on other humans, on material things and even on spiritual beliefs.

While experiencing such fears, Truth seekers can find this predicament so thrilling because of the worlds of possibility it opens up.']]), ('You’ll rescue me, right?
 In the exact same way they never did
 I’ll be happy, right?
 When your healing powers kick in
 You’ll complete me, right?
 Then my life can finally begin
 I’ll be worthy, right?
 Only when you realize the gem I am', [['The first verse begins by describing a common state of mind that all humans share at some point in their evolutions: a state of mind based on outward worldly focus where self-confidence and sense of wholeness is dependent on what others think.

In particular, in the first verse Alanis speaks of how the possibility of finding a person who could mend her life used to bring her comfort and hope about the future.']])]

annotation:
[('Because I have as much rage as you have
 I have as much pain as you do
 I’ve lived as much hell as you have
 And I’ve kept mine bubbling under for you', [['She’s highlighting and justifying the “sympathetic character” that she understands to live within herself as she’s the true victim in this abusive relationship. It’s meant to stand in stark comparison to her abuser, who is also sometimes seen as a “sympathetic character”, in her eyes, when it serves him in gaslighting her. She’s acknowledging her rage and subsequent pain in a moment of vulnerability (which is, psychologically, a power move) before warning she too possesses a similar ability to be the monster he is, towards him, perhaps even worse, yet she actively chooses not to be what she fears, because she knows first hand she’s not less than him. She can control herself. He can’t.']]), ('I was afraid of verbal daggers
 I was afraid of the calm before the storm
 I was afraid for my own bones
 I was afraid of your seduction
 I was afraid of your coercion
 I was afraid of your rejection
 I was afraid of your intimidation
 I was afraid of your punishment
 I was afraid of your icy silences
 I was afraid of your volume
 I was afraid of your manipulation
 I was afraid of your explosions', [['This is what being gaslit feels like. All of it']]), ('Sympathetic character', [['A sympathetic character is one that evokes empathy in the reader. This character might function as a self-insert, or framing for the whole story.']]), ('Testosterone', [['Testosterone, a hormone associated with male-type sexual distinction, is sometimes blamed for causing violent behavior or increasing aggression.']])]

title: So Unsexy
lyrics:
So Unsexy Lyrics[Verse 1]

When will I start staying with myself?

I jump my ship as I take it personally
And all these little rejections, how they disappear quickly
The moment I decide not to abandon me

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mindYou might also like1Embed
annotation: [('I jump my ship', [['The captain that abandons ship at the first sight of tribulation is something that has been seen time and time again. Alanis may be running away from her problems the moment she feels the ship sinking, but also may be neglecting her problems and mental health by to dealing with them. The only way she will able to progress is by facing the trial head-on and not deflecting.']]), ('I think I gave you the power to make\n Me feel the way I thought only my father could', [['A lot of women’s relationships with their fathers set up the premise for their dating life and in this lyric, Alanis is telling us that this guy is reminiscent of her father in a negative way. It brings her back to her childhood and the emotions that are tied to her father.']]), ('All these little rejections, how they seem so real to me', [['Though these rejections may be something that is in her head and overanalyzing, it still fells like the real deal and hurts her in such a vivid way']]), ('I’m 13 again, am I 13 for good?', [['Will I ever grow past the heartache I felt when I was young?(13 is a just a random young age I guess).']])]

Of unconditional things

And the door for me

[Instrumental Bridge]

annotation:
[('It’s all your fault', [['Another playful reversal. She’s lovingly teasing him as her way of thanking him. Obviously, he’s done nothing wrong—she’s not faulting him at all!']]), ('Head over feet', [['The main message of the song is about reversals, inversions, flipping the script to something unexpected: The title is a playful tweak of the idiom “head over heels,” which refers to being in love and “most likely developed from the literal meaning of falling upside down, as a way to describe the tumultuous emotions one feels while falling in love.”
https://writingexplained.org/idiom-dictionary/head-over-heels

Being in love is, from the perspective of the idiom, all about feeling turned upside down. It’s essentially about being surprised.

And yet the speaker tells her lover, “don’t be surprised.” (The effort to literally negate the surprise is itself another inversion!) Surprised about what? If she falls. Falls for him—in the typical somersault of giddy love described above? Not exactly. That kind of falling wouldn’t be surprising. Instead, she surprises him (and us) by tweaking the idiom:

While she doesn’t reverse the  imagery, she still manipulates the idiom away from what we expected. We expect to hear her say “head over heels,” but she surprises us—just as her experience of love has surprised her. For me, the imagery of “head over feet"—since it’s unfamiliar and thus doesn’t automatically evoke the same meaning as "head over heels"—seems less tumultuous than the original idiom suggests. Its plain meaning (while actually not really, on the surface, any different from the idiom that uses "heels”) seems to suggest the normal way we stand upright: our head is over our feet—the usual picture of standing “rightside up.” It’s actually about being grounded, standing tall (“feet planted firmly on the ground”), having a solid foundation for growth, for upward movement instead of chaotic tumbling—"ascending in love" as opposed to “falling in love.” So, while she says “don’t be surprised if I fall…”, she then, essentially, says that what will be surprising here will be the nature of the falling. It’ll be different—just like everything else in this relationship has been for her.']]), ('You’re my best friend
 Best friend with benefits', [['Believe it or not, this line is the origin of the infamous phrase that has made its way into the mainstream western vernacular, describing a relationship between two people that is sexual but not inherently long-term or romantic.']]), ('Your love is thick
 And it swallowed me whole
 You’re so much braver
 Than I gave you credit for
 That’s not lip service', [['talking about blowjobs folks!']]), ('You held your breath
 And the door for me', [['This is an example of zeugma. “Held” has a double meaning, one literal (“held the door”) and one metaphorical (“held your breath”).']])]

title: Hands Clean
lyrics:
Hands Clean Lyrics[Verse 1]
If it weren't for your maturity, none of this would've happened

Ooh, this could be messy
But, but you don't seem to mind, and
Ooh, don't go telling everybody, and
A overlook this supposed crime

And I know you depend on me like a young thing would to a guardian

[Pre-Chorus]

But, ooh, you don't seem to mind
Dude, don't go telling everybody
And overlook this supposed crime

[Chorus]

[Bridge]
What part of our history's reinvented and under rug swept?
What part of your memory is selective and tends to forget?
What with this distance, it seems so obvious?
You might also like[Verse 3]

We best keep this to ourselves and not tell any members of our inner posse
I wish I could tell the world 'cause you're such a pretty thing when you're done up properly
I might wanna marry you one day, if you watch that weight and keep your firm body

[Pre-Chorus]
Ooh, this could be messy, and
Ooh, I don't seem to mind, and
Ooh, don't go telling everybody
And overlook this supposed crime

[Chorus]
We'll fast forward to a few years later
And no one knows except the both of us
And I have honored your request for silence
And you've washed your hands clean of this

[Pre-Chorus]
Ooh, this could get messy, but
Ooh, I don't seem to mind
Ooh, don't go telling everybody
And overlook this supposed crime

[Chorus]
We'll fast forward to a few years later
And no one knows except the both of us
And I have honored your request for silence
And you've washed your hands clean of this
[Outro]
Ooh
Oh-oh
Oh, oh
Ooh
Ooh7Embed
annotation:
[('Ooh, this could get messy
 But, ooh, you don’t seem to mind
 Dude, don’t go telling everybody
 And overlook this supposed crime', [["Supposed crime definitely refers to statutory rape. During an interview for The New York Times, Alanis was asked about the interpretation of the song as sexual exploitation.

‘'It could be categorized as that,’‘ Morissette said, ’‘But at the same time, I’m not one to really categorize. I’m the kind of person that will say 'a person that I’ve been spending time with in a romantic way’ rather than saying ‘my boyfriend.’ So I’ll say ‘someone that I was romantically linked to at a time when I was emotionally not necessarily prepared for it,’ as opposed to qualifying it as like ‘statutory rape.’ ‘’"]]), ('If it weren’t for your maturity, none of this would’ve happened
 If you weren’t so wise beyond your years, I would’ve been able to control myself
 If it weren’t for my attention, you wouldn’t have been successful, and if
 If it weren’t for me, you would never have amounted to very much', [['The verses of this song seem to be Alanis repeating phrases that her much older lover would say about their secret relationship. In this first verse, she recites how he justified himself: it’s her fault for acting so much older than she is and being so irresistible, that she’s learning from him and wouldn’t get anywhere in life without him.

The language itself exhibits textbook grooming and victim blaming.']]), ('You’re essentially an employee and I like you having to depend on me
 You’re a kind of protégé, and one day, you’ll say you learned all you know from me, and', [['These lines suggest the man was also in the music industry. While she is young, he is helping to guide her and teach her to be successful in the industry. This also gives him an air of power and intelligence, making him more amazing in her eyes.']]), ('And I know you depend on me like a young thing would to a guardian
 I know you sexualize me like a young thing would, and I think I like ya', [['The older man she’s in a relationship with enjoyes wielding influence over her, which reinforces an imbalanced power dynamic in the relationship inherent with their age difference. It is common for young people to become infatuated with older people; he realizes this and takes full advantage of it.

It is also telling that he refers to Alanis as a “young thing” rather than a “young woman.” In a sense, that language is dehumanizing her and referring to her as an object rather than a person.']]), ('Ooh, this could be messy, and
 Ooh, I don’t seem to mind, and
 Ooh, don’t go telling everybody
 And overlook this supposed crime', [['The first time it is said the man doesn’t mind how badly everything could end. This time around, Alanis is saying she also doesn’t seem to care. She is so infatuated with this man, it’s hard to see the consequences of their actions.']]), ('I wish I could tell the world ’cause you’re such a pretty thing when you’re done up properly
 I might wanna marry you one day, if you watch that weight and keep your firm body', [['More things he told her. He would leave her on about their future. “I wish I could tell everyone about us…”, “One day, maybe we’ll get married..” And Alanis in her youth & naivete believes everything sincerely.']]), ('Just make sure you don’t tell on me, especially to members of your family
 We best keep this to ourselves and not tell any members of our inner posse', [['They know each other’s friends and family, but because they know it’s wrong to be together, the man keeps telling Alanis to keep quiet as its a secret. Her being younger, does everything he says because she believes he knows best.']]), ('What part of our history’s reinvented and under rug swept?
 What part of your memory is selective and tends to forget?
 What with this distance, it seems so obvious?', [['Sweeping things under the rug is a way of hiding the “dirty” or “unwanted” things in our life from other people’s sight. She feels their whole past has been swept under the rug and re-invented as an innocent story i.e. “Ohh, I knew Alanis when she was a young budding musician. She showed great promise and I was her musical mentor” vs. the passionate story of love she wants to tell. She feels he’s forgotten and moved on, and as the two of them grow further apart, she sees his selfish actions more and more clearly.']]), ('And I’ve more than honored your request for silence
 And you’ve washed your hands clean of this', [['Here she reiterates that she’s kept her silence as requested, but she is becoming exasperated, “I’ve MORE than done what you asked”. She needs to talk to someone about this, and writing a song was her chosen outlet method.']]), ('We’ll fast forward to a few years later
 And no one knows except the both of us
 And I have honored your request for silence
 And you’ve washed your hands clean of this', [['Years later, the affair has ended. He has told her not to tell anyone. She clearly feels hurt about the way it ended, and the fact that only the two of them know and she can’t talk to anyone about it, leaves her feeling empty and as if the affair meant nothing in the end. He was older so she just did as he asked, trusting he knew what was best. But he has walked away from everything with no consequences, and her being younger, is bearing it all alone.']])]

title: Ironic
lyrics:
Ironic Lyrics[Intro]
Hey, yeah, yeah
Yeah, ah-ah-ah, yeah, hey

[Verse 1]
An old man turned ninety-eight
He won the lottery and died the next day
It's a black fly in your Chardonnay
It's a death row pardon two minutes too late

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Verse 2]
Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
And as the plane crashed down
He thought, "Well, isn't this nice?"

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Bridge]
Well, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
When you think everything's okay and everything's going right
And life has a funny way of helping you out
When you think everything's gone wrong
And everything blows up in your face
You might also like[Verse 3]
A traffic jam when you're already late
A "No Smoking" sign on your cigarette break
It's like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife
It's meeting the man of my dreams
And then meeting his beautiful wife

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
A little too ironic
And yeah, I really do think

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Outro]
And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
Helping you out41Embed
annotation:
[('And who would’ve thought? It figures', [['Seemingly a throw-away line, the juxtaposition of these two contrary interjections neatly expresses the typical reaction to irony. An unexpected twist makes you say “Who would have thought?” but when you reflect it was almost inevitable (“It figures.”)']]), ('And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
 And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
 Helping you out', [['A bittersweet ending to a bittersweet song. Throughout the entire song, Alanis lists a number of sad, but at the same time, silly (and maybe sometimes ironic) situations that happen in people’s lives. The verses have a sad tone while the chorus is loud and cheerful. The outro says how helpless we are as human beings. We can plan our lives as much as we want but we can’t predict the future. We should accept that, and stop trying to control everything. Any little event can change the course of our entire life. What we should do is try to follow a certain path, but not be disappointed if we get sidetracked. That change of course might just be a blessing in disguise.']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?
 A little too ironic
 And yeah, I really do think', [['“Uh, no, we don’t,” said the English teachers of the world.

However, on the other hand, maybe the whole song really is ironic. Remember, irony is when things turn out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected. And Morrissette has just finished a song that is intended to illustrate the word “ironic” with a series of situations, except none of them actually turn out to be examples of irony. So the whole song turned out the opposite of how she expected.

In its own way, isn’t that ironic?']]), ('An old man turned ninety-eight
 He won the lottery and died the next day', [['It’s a pity that the old man, who had lived his whole life presumably in economical difficulty, had the chance to improve his lifestyle with a lottery win but he died the next day.

But is it ironic? No, it is not.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The old man had played the lottery specifically to get money to pay for heart surgery, but the excitement of finding out he’d won triggered a fatal heart attack.

Remember the definition of ironic:


using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny

strange or funny because something (such as a situation) is different from what you expected']]), ('It’s a black fly in your Chardonnay', [['Nobody wants a fly in anything they eat or drink, including a nice glass of white wine like Chardonnay. (Except of course people who enjoy eating insects.)

But that doesn’t make it ironic. Irony is when a situation turns out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected.

This MIGHT be ironic if:


You had deliberately decided to drink Chardonnay because you believed it was the beverage least likely to contain flies.
You had spent all day killing the flies in your home and, believing that you had successfully killed every single one of them, opened a bottle of Chardonnay to celebrate and discovered a fly in it.





Come on Alanis, it’s just protein!']]), ('It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife', [['Irish comedian Ed Byrne did a brilliant skit about “Ironic” back in 1998. He went to town on the lyrics, but saved his takedown of this line until last.

The best line in that song, the best line ever written, ever, has got to be the line ‘It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife’. That’s not ironic – that’s just stupid. How big is your sink, Alanis? Come on![…]What do you need a knife for? To stab the bastard who keeps leaving spoons all over your house?

Byrne went on to give a scenario in which the line would make sense:

Imagine you needed a knife for something, couldn’t find one cos all you found was ten thousand spoons and therefore couldn’t do whatever it was you needed the knife for. And then the next day, turned out that a spoon would’ve done…

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZOZG1Ob6po']]), ('Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
 He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
 He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
 And as the plane crashed down
 He thought, “Well, isn’t this nice?”', [['More tragic than ironic.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The man was in a plane crash even though he had deliberately researched and chose an airline that was noted for its safety record, like Qantas.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qmF1Lh4f3OM

However, in the end, the song accidentally gets this one right.

That’s because when the man thinks to himself, “Well, isn’t this nice…?” he is thinking the opposite of what he means. Luckily for Morrissette, this fits the other dictionary definition of ironic:

using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?', [['A lot of people say no.

Even Alanis joked about it herself in the revisited version of the song performed on the Late Show with James Corden with the line: “It’s singing "Ironic,” but there are no ironies"']]), ('It’s a death row pardon two minutes too late', [['Now that just sucks – too bad they won’t ever have to know…

This is incredibly tragic and all too real. According to a study by Northwestern University, at least 39 innocent people have been wrongfully executed in the United States.

It is tragic, unjust, and worrisome. BUT – is it ironic? No.']])]

title: That Particular Time
lyrics:
That Particular Time Lyrics[Verse 1]
My foundation was rocked
My tried and true way to deal was to vanish
My departures were old, I stood in the room shaking in my boots
At that particular time love had challenged me to stay
At that particular moment I knew not to run away again
That particular month I was ready to investigate with you
At that particular time

[Verse 2]
We thought a break would be good
For four months, we sat and vacillated
We thought a small time apart would clear up the doubts that were abounding
At that particular time love encouraged me to wait
At that particular moment it helped me to be patient
That particular month we needed time to marinate in what "us" meant
At that particular time
[Verse 3]
I've always wanted for you what you've wanted for yourself
And yet I wanted to save us high water or hell
And I kept on ignoring the ambivalence you felt
And in the meantime, I lost myself
In the meantime, I lost myself
I'm sorry I lost myself - I am

[Verse 4]
You knew you needed more time, time spent alone with no distraction
You felt you needed to fly, solo and high to define what you wanted
At that particular time love encouraged me to leave
At that particular moment I knew staying with you meant deserting me

title: Thank U
lyrics:
Thank U Lyrics[Verse 1]
How 'bout getting off of these antibiotics
How 'bout stopping eating when I'm full up
How 'bout them transparent dangling carrots
How 'bout that ever elusive kudo

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence
[Verse 2]
How 'bout me not blaming you for everything
How 'bout me enjoying the moment for once
How 'bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
How 'bout grieving it all one at a time

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence

[Bridge]
The moment I let go of it
Was the moment I got more than I could handle
The moment I jumped off of it
Was the moment I touched down

[Verse 3]
How 'bout no longer being masochistic
How 'bout remembering your divinity
How 'bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
How 'bout not equating death with stopping
You might also like[Chorus 2]
Thank you India
Thank you providence
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you nothingness
Thank you clarity
Thank you, thank you silence

[Outro]
Yeah, yeah
Oh, oh, oh-oh
No, oh, oh, oh
No, oh, oh, oh12Embed
annotation:
[('Thank you India', [['In between Jagged Little Pill and Supposed former infatuation junkie. Alanis took a break and traveled to India. This song is a reflection of her trip.']]), ('How ’bout no longer being masochistic
 How ’bout remembering your divinity
 How ’bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
 How ’bout not equating death with stopping', [["Again, the core of the song’s message, here we see a side that’s a tad darker. We are told to love ourselves and not be masochistic. “Remembering our divinity” is most likely about faith in embetterment, and that we can change if we believe enough.
Crying is, to most people, a very cathartic process and helps them get over the sadness and anger that they feel and reach a more serene state of mind. Alanis feels that we should be able to do so unapologetically.

The line about “not equating death with stopping” stems from one of Alanis' interviews. She said that when the tour for Jagged Little Pill was over, she finally sat in her room, doing nothing and she said she felt like she was dead, but a good kind of death. She now believes that we should not feel dead if we stop doing something that exhausts us, and that we should be thankful: firstly, for being able to do that thing in the first place; and secondly that we were able to stop."]]), ('How ’bout me not blaming you for everything
 How ’bout me enjoying the moment for once
 How ’bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
 How ’bout grieving it all one at a time', [['The whole song is a rumination of what we can and should do to better ourselves, and this is the core message of it. How about instead of blaming each others, we forgive, we enjoy life and all it has to offer. Sure, it won’t all be rainbows and butterflies, but living in the moment, not in the “what ifs” and “could’ve”, and just take life as it comes at us.']]), ('Thank you terror
 Thank you disillusionment
 Thank you frailty
 Thank you consequence
 Thank you, thank you silence', [['Here, Alanis acknowledges that everything that is a part of our lives helps us grow. A sort of a countinuation of “You Learn”’s theme, she thanks everything that made her the person she is today, while most people tend to dread these sorts of feelings.']]), ('How ’bout stopping eating when I’m full up
 How ’bout them transparent dangling carrots
 How ’bout that ever elusive kudo', [['Alanis muses over failings that people from western civilizations, and by extension, she herself, feels trapped in and that hat her mystical wanderings have brought to her attention, enabling her to begin to fix them.

We tend to “eat even when we’re full”, meaning that we love excesses, we love having a goal, and punishing ourselves over the things we “could have”. This is a very odd approach for what everyone pigeonholed Alanis to be: an angry woman, and it is a much more serene approach to life.']]), ('The moment I let go of it
 Was the moment I got more than I could handle
 The moment I jumped off of it
 Was the moment I touched down', [['Here the author realizes that she was trying to carry more she was able to.
When she let it go she could see it from a different perspective.']])]

title: Out Is Through
lyrics:
Out Is Through Lyrics[Verse 1]
Every time you raise your voice, I see the greener grass
Every time you run for cover, I see this pasture
Every time we're in a funk, I picture a different choice
Anytime we're in a rut, this distant grandeur

My tendency to want to do away feels natural and
My urgency to dream of softer places feels understandable
But I know

The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately

[Verse 2]

Every time our horns are locked on towel throwing
Every time we're at a loss, we've bolted from difficulty
Anytime we're in stalemate, a final bowing

My tendency to want to hide away feels easier and
The immediacy is picturing another place comforting to go

[Chorus]
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately
You might also like[Bridge]
We could just walk away and hide our heads in the sand
We could just call it quits, only to start all over again
With somebody else

[Verse 3]
Every time we're stuck in struggle, I'm down for the count that day
Every time I dream of quick fix, I'm swaged
Now I know it's hard when it's through and I'm damned if I don't know quick fix way
But formerly mistreat me silence now outdated

[Pre-Chorus 2]
My tendency to want to run feels unnatural now
The urgency to want to give to you I don't want most feels good
And I know

[Chorus]
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll get better
The only way out is through ultimately2Embed
annotation:
[('Every time our horns are locked on towel throwing', [["To lock horns with someone means to get into an argument with someone. Boxers' trainers throw the towel into the ring to sign that one of the fighters needs to quit the match and is defeated.

In this context she’s saying that they argue about her tendency to not face things directly and to avoid her responsibilities in their relationship."]]), ('My tendency to want to do away feels natural and
 My urgency to dream of softer places feels understandable
 But I know', [['Her tendency, as she points out in the verses, is to avoid her problems and try not to think about them instead of facing them. She finds comfort in her dreams and in her imagination.

She acknowledges that her desire to avoid facing her problems is human and is understandable, but she knows that will not take her anywhere in the long term.']]), ('The only way out is through
 The faster we’re in, the better
 The only way out is through ultimately
 The only way out is through
 The only way we’ll feel better
 The only way out is through ultimately', [['The only way out of life’s problems is to face them and get through them. If you don’t face them, they are going to stay with you for the rest of your life and you’ll never be free or happy. The sooner you realize that and do something about it, the less consequences you’ll have to face and the less damage you’ll have to endure.

To be noted that this song follows the same lyrical structure that can be found in “Excuses” and “Spineless”: in the verse she lists her wrongful tendencies, in the pre-chorus she admits her faults and in the chorus she offers a way to resolve her issues, which is to face them, ultimately.']]), ('Every time you raise your voice, I see the greener grass
 Every time you run for cover, I see this pasture
 Every time we’re in a funk, I picture a different choice
 Anytime we’re in a rut, this distant grandeur', [['She is in a relationship but every time they have a problem, she escapes the conversation and she avoids taking her responsibilities and her part of the blame when things aren’t working.

The “pasture” is this empty, dreamy place in her mind where she runs to when they have a discussion or a fight.']])]

title: Excuses
lyrics:
Excuses Lyrics[Verse 1]
Why no one will help me?

It's too hard to help me

[Verse 2]

They've kept me safe
They've kept me stoic
They've kept me locked in my own cell

[Chorus 2]

They've kept me blocked
They've kept me small
They've kept me safe inside my shell

[Bridge]
Bringing these into light shakes their foundation
And it clears my sight
Now my imagination is the only thing that limits
The bar and its rise to the heights

[Verse 3]
No one can have it all see
I have to, they want me to
And I can't let them down
I will never be happy
You might also like[Chorus 1]
These excuses, how they served me so well
They've kept me safe
They've kept me stoic
They've kept me locked in my own cell

[Chorus 2]
These excuses, how they're so familiar
They've kept me blocked
They've kept me small
They've kept me safe inside my shell1Embed
annotation:
[('Now my imagination is the only thing that limits
 The bar and its rise to the heights', [['She realizes that the only thing holding her back is her own thoughts and mindset.']]), ('Bringing these into light shakes their foundation
 And it clears my sight', [['Acknowledging her tendency to invent excuses and being dishonest with herself and the others around her helps her realizing that this is not the right thing to do and that she needs to get up and do something about it.']]), ('I’m too far from home
 It takes far too much energy
 And I cannot afford to
 No one will ever see me', [['That’s an excuse she tells herself to justify her distance and lack of contact with her family and loved ones. She uses her lack of time and energy as an excuse to not feel guilty about it.']]), ('And God wants me to work
 No resting, no lazy', [['Again, she shields herself from other people, this time by being a workaholic. She feels guilty that she doesn’t want to face her problems so she limits her life to work and she excludes fun and free-time activities that would feel “undeserved” for her.



God here is used an excuse to support her escapism from her reality through hard work. There are about 60 verses in the Bible referencing and supporting hard work in the name of God.']]), ('And there is not enough time
 It’s too hard to help me', [['She wants to discourage anyone who’s willing to help her by saying that she’s too damaged to be helped.

That is an excuse to not face her problems.']]), ('They’ll not understand me
 I am lonely, they’ll hate me', [['She avoids connection with other people, saying that they won’t understand her, that they will “hate her”.



That of course is an excuse not to get out of her shell and face her issues regarding having to do with new people and keeping in contact with her long-time friendships.']]), ('These excuses, how they served me so well
 They’ve kept me safe
 They’ve kept me stoic
 They’ve kept me locked in my own cell', [['In this song, her tendency exposed is to find excuses in order to keep herself isolated and not face interrelationship with other people.

The excuses kept her “stoic” in the sense that they kept her distant from her emotions and from the rest of the world. Here, “stoic” is used as a synonym of “apathetic”.



That shields her from any form of damage of suffering, at the price of being alone and not living life at its fullest.']])]

title: Doth I Protest Too Much

You might also like[Chorus 1]

Not going insane, rational stays in touch
And doth I protest too much?Embed
annotation:
[('So much energy to prove to you, I am not
 Who you aim for me to be', [["it sounds like her boyfriend is trying to get her attention in a negative way, but it probably is Alanis' trying to deny the attention."]]), ('I’m not disappointed, about how you don’t miss me', [['This line indicates she discovers her boyfriend is cheating on her, and she pretends to be ignoring it.']]), ('I’m not tortured by how oft you’re busy
 ’Cause I’ve got things to do', [['she is in a state of denial and worry that her boyfriend is cheating as most of the time, when a man says to his wife/girlfriend that he is busy at work, this is a stereotype and hint to their infidelity.']]), ('I’m not jealous, I don’t get moved by much
 I’m not enraged, not insecure as such
 Not going insane, rational stays in touch
 And doth I protest too much?', [['Alanis states here that she doesn’t want to be jealous of her man’s flirtatious greetings, but can’t admit that it is happening at all, therefore she is protesting even if she chooses not to be jealous.']]), ('I’m secure, and out of me, it’s hard to get a rise', [['she worries that her boyfriend is too interested in other women he sees that someday he’ll leave her for another woman.']])]

annotation:
[('You dig everything of which I’m ashamed
 There’s not anything to which you can’t relate
 And you’re still here', [['As opposed to the relationship presented in the previous song, “Spineless”, this song sees Alanis involved in a relationship that makes her grow to love herself for who she is. Her love interest helps her overcoming her shame about the things she doesn’t like about herself and he connects to her on many levels. As a results she’s learning how to accept herself too.

She remarks that “he’s still here”, almost as if she was surprised, meaning she’s never believed she could connect so much with someone and a relationship based on openness and sincerity could last this long.']]), ('You see everything, you see every part
 You see all my light and you love my dark', [['You know it’s true love when you find someone that sees every bit of yourself, your qualities and your faults, and they still make you feel accepted and loved.']])]

title: Offer
lyrics:
Offer Lyrics[Verse 1]
Who
Who am I to be blue?
Look at my family and fortune
Look at my friends and my house
Who
Who am I to feel dead end?
Who am I to feel spent?
Look at my health and my money
And where
Where do I go to feel good?
Why do I still look outside me?
When clearly I've seen it won't work
[Chorus]
Is it my calling to keep on when I'm unable?
And is it my job to be selfless extraordinaire?
And my generosity has me disabled
By this my sense of duty to offer

[Verse 2]
And why
Why do I feel so ungrateful?
Me who is far beyond survival
Me who see life as an oyster

[Chorus]
Is it my calling to keep on when I'm unable?
And is it my job to be selfless extraordinaire?
And my generosity has me disabled
By this my sense of duty to offer

[Verse 3]
And how
How dare I rest on my laurels
How dare I ignore an outstretched hand
How dare I ignore a third world country

[Chorus]
Is it my calling to keep on when I'm unable?
And is it my job to be selfless extraordinaire?
And my generosity has me disabled
By this my sense of duty to offer
You might also like[Outro]
Who
Who am I to be, woo1Embed
annotation:
[('Who am I to be, woo', [['I’ve always been somewhat confused by the inclusion of the word “woo”. There are two definitions that could fit here:


seek the favor, support, or custom of.
try to gain the love of (someone).



This could go back to the feeling of “my needs don’t matter”. How dare she try to get others to attend to her needs for once, right?

It could also be an unknowing reference to the desire and the fear of the Two: to feel needed, and a fear of being unloved.

The Two is in the Rejection Triad – if I present my needs to people, I may be rejected. Therefor I must sacrifice myself and be a safe place for them instead so that I am not alone and unwanted.']]), ('And how
 How dare I rest on my laurels
 How dare I ignore an outstretched hand
 How dare I ignore a third world country', [['Yes, let’s take on the weight of the world, Alanis. Don’t ever rest.']]), ('Me who is far beyond survival
 Me who see life as an oyster', [['Because of her successful career, the world is her oyster – a phrase meaning that one is in a position to take the opportunities that life has to offer.']]), ('And why
 Why do I feel so ungrateful?', [['This is echoing the first verse. Why should she be allowed to feel anything but a humble gratefulness?']]), ('Is it my calling to keep on when I’m unable?
 And is it my job to be selfless extraordinaire?
 And my generosity has me disabled
 By this my sense of duty to offer', [['These are lyrics by a self-aware Two. She realizes that this is unhealthy but Twos have a desire to be needed and a fear of being unloved. But again, she is self-aware and realizes that this is disabling her.']]), ('And where
 Where do I go to feel good?
 Why do I still look outside me?
 When clearly I’ve seen it won’t work', [['In order to have self worth, she feels she must go out and serve as she has been taught all her life. She is realizing that this isn’t working.']]), ('Who
 Who am I to be blue?
 Look at my family and fortune
 Look at my friends and my house
 Who
 Who am I to feel dead end?
 Who am I to feel spent?
 Look at my health and my money', [['This is a classic Two – “my needs don’t matter”. In this verse, “my emotional needs don’t matter, look at what I have! How could I let myself feel anything but gratefulness for what I have?”']])]

title: Sister Blister
lyrics:
Sister Blister Lyrics[Verse 1]
You and me, we're cut from the same cloth
It seems to some we famously get along
But you and me are strangers to each other
'Cause you and me: competitive to the bone

[Pre-Chorus]
Such tragedy to trample on each other
With how much we've endured, with the state this land is in
You and me feel joined only by gender
We are not all for one and one for all
[Chorus]
Sister blister, we fight to please the brothers
We think their acceptance is how we win
They're happy we're climbing over each other
To beg the club of boys to let us in

[Verse 2]
You and me, estranged from the mother
You and me have felt impotent in our skin
You and me have taken it out on each other
And you and me disloyal to the feminine

[Pre-Chorus]
Such a pity to disavow each other
With how far we've come, with how strong we've been
You and me are on this pendulum together
You and me with scarcity still fueling

[Chorus]
Sister blister, we fight to please the brothers
We think their acceptance is how we win
They're happy we're climbing over each other
To beg the club of boys to let us in

[Bridge]
We may not have priorities same
We may not even like each other
We may not be hugely anti-men
But such a cost to dishonor a sister
You might also like[Verse 3]
You and me have made it harder for the other
We forget how hard separatism has been
You and me, we can help change their minds together
You and me in alignment until the end

[Chorus]
Sister blister, we fight to please the brothers
We think their acceptance is how we win
They're happy we're climbing over each other
To beg the club of boys to let us in
Sister blister, we fight to please the brothers
We think their acceptance is how we win
They're happy we're climbing over each other
To beg the club of boys to let us inEmbed

title: So Unsexy
lyrics:
So Unsexy Lyrics[Verse 1]
All these little rejections, how they add up quickly
One small sideways look and I feel so ungood
And somewhere along the way, I think I gave you the power to make
Me feel the way I thought only my father could
All these little rejections, how they seem so real to me
One forgotten birthday, I'm all but cooked
And how these little abandonments seem to sting so easily
I'm 13 again, am I 13 for good?

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind
[Verse 2]
All these little protections, how they fail to serve me
One forgotten phone call and I'm deflated
And all these little defenses, how they fail to comfort me
Your hand pulling away and I'm devastated

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind

[Bridge]
When will I stop leaving, baby?
When will I stop deserting, baby?
When will I start staying with myself?

[Verse 3]
All these little projections, how they keep springing from me
I jump my ship as I take it personally
And all these little rejections, how they disappear quickly
The moment I decide not to abandon me

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mindYou might also like1Embed
annotation: [('I jump my ship', [['The captain that abandons ship at the first sight of tribulation is something that has been seen time and time again. Alanis may be running away from her problems the moment she feels the ship sinking, but also may be neglecting her problems and mental health by to dealing with them. The only way she will able to progress is by facing the trial head-on and not deflecting.']]), ('I think I gave you the power to make\n Me feel the way I thought only my father could', [['A lot of women’s relationships with their fathers set up the premise for their dating life and in this lyric, Alanis is telling us that this guy is reminiscent of her father in a negative way. It brings her back to her childhood and the emotions that are tied to her father.']]), ('All these little rejections, how they seem so real to me', [['Though these rejections may be something that is in her head and overanalyzing, it still fells like the real deal and hurts her in such a vivid way']]), ('I’m 13 again, am I 13 for good?', [['Will I ever grow past the heartache I felt when I was young?(13 is a just a random young age I guess).']])]

title: Precious Illusions
lyrics:
Precious Illusions Lyrics[Verse 1]
You'll rescue me, right?
In the exact same way they never did
I'll be happy, right?
When your healing powers kick in
You'll complete me, right?
Then my life can finally begin
I'll be worthy, right?
Only when you realize the gem I am

[Pre-Chorus 1]
But this won't work now the way it once did
And I won't keep it up even though I would love to
Once I know who I'm not then I'll know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim
[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends

[Verse 2]
This ring will help me yet
As will you, knight in shining armor
This pill will help me yet
As will these boys gone through like water

[Pre-Chorus 2]
But this won't work as well as the way it once did
Because I want to decide between survival and bliss
And though I know who I'm not I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend

[Bridge]
I've spent so long firmly looking outside me
I've spent so much time living in survival mode
You might also like[Pre-Chorus 3]
This won't work now the way it once did
'Cause I want to decide between survival and bliss
Now I know who I'm not, I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend2Embed
annotation:
[('This ring will help me yet
 As will you, knight in shining armor
 This pill will help me yet
 As will these boys gone through like water', [['In this verse, Alanis catalogs the different ways she can “fix” herself: getting married, finding the right guy, taking drugs, sleeping with lots of guys. None of them work, obviously.']]), ('Survival and bliss', [['Alanis is obviously looking at the thought-patterns in her psyche that are ego-based, which are also survival-based (survival of the ego, of the identity). I imagine she is recognizing that these sub-conscious patterns have limited her experience of life. And here, she is seeking bliss instead.

Philosophically speaking, ‘bliss’ is not the only word that fits here. We could insert ‘truth’, ‘freedom’, ‘peace’, or ‘joy’ here as well.']]), ('These precious illusions in my head
 Did not let me down when I was defenseless
 And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends', [["Alanis' precious illusion – which is a pretty common illusion, especially in early age – was that she might one day find someone who give her a reason to be. In the second verse she also implies that she used to find solace and hope in material things, like the “magical pill” that could solve all her problems.

However, these illusions were her “best friend” when she was “a kid”, which could also metaphorically allude to a person who was new to life and still had a lot to learn. Now that she’s acknowledged that these thoughts don’t work in real life and aren’t going to sustain her any longer she can’t just pretend, she has to get rid of them."]]), ('But I know I won’t keep on playing the victim', [['It’s so easy to pass responsibility onto everyone else and this is a great strategy of the ego. As soon as Alanis acknowledges that she can’t rely on someone else to feel as a whole, to mend herself and to finally begin her life, she decides to take all the responsibility of what she will go through.

She may not know who she is yet, but at least she realized that it doesn’t matter as long as she might find it out by herself in the future and in the meantime she’s living like there’s no tomorrow.']]), ('Once I know who I’m not then I’ll know who I am', [['‘Who am I?’ always has been and always will be the ultimate question. Great philosophers for millennia have asked it, and most have great difficulty answering it.

Alanis appears to have chosen to use the strategy of deduction: if I’m not ready to answer ‘Who am I?’, then I may answer ‘Who am I not?’ And of course this is a work in progress. Psychologists often use the ‘onion analogy’, whereby one must peel away layer by layer by layer to get to the center of one’s psyche.']]), ('But this won’t work now the way it once did
 And I won’t keep it up even though I would love to', [['Once Alanis found out that these thoughts aren’t going to bring her comfort any longer, she just decides to drop them and find the truth in something else.

There comes a point in one’s journey, often times at a low point, when a soul realizes that all her strategies for happiness and wholeness simply have not served her. This can be very scary as humans tend to depend on other humans, on material things and even on spiritual beliefs.

While experiencing such fears, Truth seekers can find this predicament so thrilling because of the worlds of possibility it opens up.']]), ('You’ll rescue me, right?
 In the exact same way they never did
 I’ll be happy, right?
 When your healing powers kick in
 You’ll complete me, right?
 Then my life can finally begin
 I’ll be worthy, right?
 Only when you realize the gem I am', [['The first verse begins by describing a common state of mind that all humans share at some point in their evolutions: a state of mind based on outward worldly focus where self-confidence and sense of wholeness is dependent on what others think.

In particular, in the first verse Alanis speaks of how the possibility of finding a person who could mend her life used to bring her comfort and hope about the future.']])]

title: A Man
lyrics:
A Man Lyrics[Verse 1]
I am a man, as a man I've been told
Bacon is brought to the house in this mold
Born of your bellies, I yearn for the cord
Years I have groveled, repentance ignored

[Chorus 1]
And I have been blamed
And I have repented
I'm working my way toward our union mended
[Verse 2]
I am man who has grown from a son
Been crucified by enraged women
I am a son who was raised by such men
I'm often reminded of the fools I'm among

[Chorus 2]
And I have been shamed
And I have relented
I'm working my way toward our union mended
And I have been shamed
And I have repented
I'm working my way toward our union mended

[Bridge]
We don't fare well with endless reprimands
And we don't do well with a life served as a sentence
And this won't work well if you're hell bent on your offense
'Cause I am a man who understands your reticence

[Verse 3]
I am a man who still does what he can
To dispel our archaic reputation
I am a man who has heard all he can
'Cause I don't fare well with endless punishment
You might also like[Chorus 3]
'Cause I have been blamed
And I have repented
I'm working my way toward our union mended
And we have been blamed
And we have repented
I'm working my way toward our union mended

[Bridge]
We don't fare well with endless reprimands
And we don't do well with a life served as a sentence
And this won't work well if you're hell bent on your offense
'cause I am a man who understands your reticence1Embed

title: Spineless
lyrics:
Spineless Lyrics[Verse 1]
I won't see my dear friends as much
Male friends especially, I'll no longer be in touch
I'll change my hobbies to match yours

[Verse 2]
I'll stop reading my favorite books
I won't spend all this selfish time alone
I'll cater to you and hang on your every word

[Chorus]
I'll be subservient and spineless
I'll lick your boots as empty shells
I'll be opinionless and silent
I'll be the prettiest appendage to ever lose herself
[Verse 3]
I'll redefine self-sacrifice
Live my life as apologetic compromise
I know you'd leave if I rocked the boat

[Chorus]
I'll be subservient and spineless
I'll lick your boots as empty shells
I'll be opinionless and silent
I'll be the prettiest appendage to ever lose herself

[Bridge]
I feel this, truly proclaimed
Will help the curbing of this tendency
I know this sharing of shame
Will ensure that I won't forget myself so easily

[Verse 4]
I'll be low maintenance and agreeable
I will not talk about my dreams so much
I'll listen to you for hours, won't need anything

[Chorus]
I'll be subservient and spineless
I'll lick your boots as empty shells
I'll be opinionless and silent
I'll be the prettiest appendage to ever lose herself
You might also likeI'll be subservient and spineless
I'll lick your boots as empty shells
I'll be opinionless and silent
I'll be the prettiest appendage to ever lose herself

[Outro]
I feel this, truly proclaimed
Will help the curbing of this tendency
I know this sharing of shame
Will ensure that I won't forget myself
I feel this, truly proclaimed
Will help the curbing of this tendency
I know this sharing of fame
Will ensure that I won't forget myself so easily1Embed

title: This Grudge
lyrics:
This Grudge Lyrics[Verse 1]
Fourteen years, thirty minutes
Fifteen seconds I've held this grudge
Eleven songs, four full journals
Thoughts of punishment I've expended

[Verse 2]
Not in contact, not a letter
Such communication, telepathic
You've been vilified, used as fodder
You deserve a piece of every record
[Pre-Chorus 1]
But who's it hurting now?
Who's the one that's stuck?
And who's it torturing now
With an antique knot in her stomach?

[Chorus]
I wanna be big and let go
Of this grudge that's grown old
All this time I've not known
How to rest this bygone
I wanna be soft and resolved
Clean of slate and released
I wanna forgive for the both of us

[Verse 3]
Like an abandoned house, dusty covered
Furniture, still intact
If I visit it now, do I simply re-live it?
Somehow gratuitous

[Pre-Chorus 2]
But who's still aching now?
Who's tired of her own voice?
Who is it weighing down
With no gift from time of said healing?

Of this grudge that's grown old
All this time I've not known
How to rest this bygone
I wanna be soft and resolved
Clean of slate and released
I wanna forgive for the both of us

[Bridge]
Maybe as I cut the cord
Veils will lift from my eyes
Maybe as I lay this to rest
Dead weight off my shoulders to rise

[Verse 4]
Here I sit much determined
Ever ill-equipped to draw this curtain
How this has entertained, validated
And has served me greatly, ever the victim

[Pre-Chorus 3]
But who's done whining now?
Who's ready to put down?
This load I've carried longer
Than I had cared to remember
[Chorus]
I wanna be big and let go
Of this grudge that's grown old
For the life of me I've not known
How to rest this bygone
I wanna be soft and resolved
Clean of slate and released
I wanna forgive for the both of us

annotation: [('But who’s it hurting now?\n Who’s the one that’s stuck?', [['Holding grudges only hurts yourself, not the person you are holding it against.']])]

title: Out Is Through
lyrics:
Out Is Through Lyrics[Verse 1]
Every time you raise your voice, I see the greener grass
Every time you run for cover, I see this pasture
Every time we're in a funk, I picture a different choice
Anytime we're in a rut, this distant grandeur

[Pre-Chorus 1]
My tendency to want to do away feels natural and
My urgency to dream of softer places feels understandable
But I know
[Chorus]
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately

[Verse 2]
Every time that I'm confused, I think there must be easier ways
Every time our horns are locked on towel throwing
Every time we're at a loss, we've bolted from difficulty
Anytime we're in stalemate, a final bowing

[Pre-Chorus 2]
My tendency to want to hide away feels easier and
The immediacy is picturing another place comforting to go

[Chorus]
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately
You might also like[Bridge]
We could just walk away and hide our heads in the sand
We could just call it quits, only to start all over again
With somebody else

[Verse 3]
Every time we're stuck in struggle, I'm down for the count that day
Every time I dream of quick fix, I'm swaged
Now I know it's hard when it's through and I'm damned if I don't know quick fix way
But formerly mistreat me silence now outdated

[Pre-Chorus 2]
My tendency to want to run feels unnatural now
The urgency to want to give to you I don't want most feels good
And I know

[Chorus]
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll feel better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The faster we're in, the better
The only way out is through ultimately
The only way out is through
The only way we'll get better
The only way out is through ultimately2Embed
annotation:
[('Every time our horns are locked on towel throwing', [["To lock horns with someone means to get into an argument with someone. Boxers' trainers throw the towel into the ring to sign that one of the fighters needs to quit the match and is defeated.

In this context she’s saying that they argue about her tendency to not face things directly and to avoid her responsibilities in their relationship."]]), ('My tendency to want to do away feels natural and
 My urgency to dream of softer places feels understandable
 But I know', [['Her tendency, as she points out in the verses, is to avoid her problems and try not to think about them instead of facing them. She finds comfort in her dreams and in her imagination.

She acknowledges that her desire to avoid facing her problems is human and is understandable, but she knows that will not take her anywhere in the long term.']]), ('The only way out is through
 The faster we’re in, the better
 The only way out is through ultimately
 The only way out is through
 The only way we’ll feel better
 The only way out is through ultimately', [['The only way out of life’s problems is to face them and get through them. If you don’t face them, they are going to stay with you for the rest of your life and you’ll never be free or happy. The sooner you realize that and do something about it, the less consequences you’ll have to face and the less damage you’ll have to endure.

To be noted that this song follows the same lyrical structure that can be found in “Excuses” and “Spineless”: in the verse she lists her wrongful tendencies, in the pre-chorus she admits her faults and in the chorus she offers a way to resolve her issues, which is to face them, ultimately.']]), ('Every time you raise your voice, I see the greener grass
 Every time you run for cover, I see this pasture
 Every time we’re in a funk, I picture a different choice
 Anytime we’re in a rut, this distant grandeur', [['She is in a relationship but every time they have a problem, she escapes the conversation and she avoids taking her responsibilities and her part of the blame when things aren’t working.

The “pasture” is this empty, dreamy place in her mind where she runs to when they have a discussion or a fight.']])]

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends

[Verse 2]
This ring will help me yet
As will you, knight in shining armor
This pill will help me yet
As will these boys gone through like water

[Pre-Chorus 2]
But this won't work as well as the way it once did
Because I want to decide between survival and bliss
And though I know who I'm not I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend

[Bridge]
I've spent so long firmly looking outside me
I've spent so much time living in survival mode
You might also like[Pre-Chorus 3]
This won't work now the way it once did
'Cause I want to decide between survival and bliss
Now I know who I'm not, I still don't know who I am
But I know I won't keep on playing the victim

[Chorus]
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was defenseless
And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends
These precious illusions in my head
Did not let me down when I was a kid
And parting with them is like parting with a childhood best friend2Embed
annotation:
[('This ring will help me yet
 As will you, knight in shining armor
 This pill will help me yet
 As will these boys gone through like water', [['In this verse, Alanis catalogs the different ways she can “fix” herself: getting married, finding the right guy, taking drugs, sleeping with lots of guys. None of them work, obviously.']]), ('Survival and bliss', [['Alanis is obviously looking at the thought-patterns in her psyche that are ego-based, which are also survival-based (survival of the ego, of the identity). I imagine she is recognizing that these sub-conscious patterns have limited her experience of life. And here, she is seeking bliss instead.

Philosophically speaking, ‘bliss’ is not the only word that fits here. We could insert ‘truth’, ‘freedom’, ‘peace’, or ‘joy’ here as well.']]), ('These precious illusions in my head
 Did not let me down when I was defenseless
 And parting with them is like parting with invisible best friends', [["Alanis' precious illusion – which is a pretty common illusion, especially in early age – was that she might one day find someone who give her a reason to be. In the second verse she also implies that she used to find solace and hope in material things, like the “magical pill” that could solve all her problems.

However, these illusions were her “best friend” when she was “a kid”, which could also metaphorically allude to a person who was new to life and still had a lot to learn. Now that she’s acknowledged that these thoughts don’t work in real life and aren’t going to sustain her any longer she can’t just pretend, she has to get rid of them."]]), ('But I know I won’t keep on playing the victim', [['It’s so easy to pass responsibility onto everyone else and this is a great strategy of the ego. As soon as Alanis acknowledges that she can’t rely on someone else to feel as a whole, to mend herself and to finally begin her life, she decides to take all the responsibility of what she will go through.

She may not know who she is yet, but at least she realized that it doesn’t matter as long as she might find it out by herself in the future and in the meantime she’s living like there’s no tomorrow.']]), ('Once I know who I’m not then I’ll know who I am', [['‘Who am I?’ always has been and always will be the ultimate question. Great philosophers for millennia have asked it, and most have great difficulty answering it.

Alanis appears to have chosen to use the strategy of deduction: if I’m not ready to answer ‘Who am I?’, then I may answer ‘Who am I not?’ And of course this is a work in progress. Psychologists often use the ‘onion analogy’, whereby one must peel away layer by layer by layer to get to the center of one’s psyche.']]), ('But this won’t work now the way it once did
 And I won’t keep it up even though I would love to', [['Once Alanis found out that these thoughts aren’t going to bring her comfort any longer, she just decides to drop them and find the truth in something else.

There comes a point in one’s journey, often times at a low point, when a soul realizes that all her strategies for happiness and wholeness simply have not served her. This can be very scary as humans tend to depend on other humans, on material things and even on spiritual beliefs.

While experiencing such fears, Truth seekers can find this predicament so thrilling because of the worlds of possibility it opens up.']]), ('You’ll rescue me, right?
 In the exact same way they never did
 I’ll be happy, right?
 When your healing powers kick in
 You’ll complete me, right?
 Then my life can finally begin
 I’ll be worthy, right?
 Only when you realize the gem I am', [['The first verse begins by describing a common state of mind that all humans share at some point in their evolutions: a state of mind based on outward worldly focus where self-confidence and sense of wholeness is dependent on what others think.

In particular, in the first verse Alanis speaks of how the possibility of finding a person who could mend her life used to bring her comfort and hope about the future.']])]

title: So Unsexy
lyrics:
So Unsexy Lyrics[Verse 1]

Me feel the way I thought only my father could

One forgotten birthday, I'm all but cooked

I'm 13 again, am I 13 for good?

I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind

So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind

[Bridge]
When will I stop leaving, baby?
When will I stop deserting, baby?
When will I start staying with myself?

[Verse 3]
All these little projections, how they keep springing from me
I jump my ship as I take it personally
And all these little rejections, how they disappear quickly
The moment I decide not to abandon me

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mindYou might also like1Embed
annotation: [('I jump my ship', [['The captain that abandons ship at the first sight of tribulation is something that has been seen time and time again. Alanis may be running away from her problems the moment she feels the ship sinking, but also may be neglecting her problems and mental health by to dealing with them. The only way she will able to progress is by facing the trial head-on and not deflecting.']]), ('I think I gave you the power to make\n Me feel the way I thought only my father could', [['A lot of women’s relationships with their fathers set up the premise for their dating life and in this lyric, Alanis is telling us that this guy is reminiscent of her father in a negative way. It brings her back to her childhood and the emotions that are tied to her father.']]), ('All these little rejections, how they seem so real to me', [['Though these rejections may be something that is in her head and overanalyzing, it still fells like the real deal and hurts her in such a vivid way']]), ('I’m 13 again, am I 13 for good?', [['Will I ever grow past the heartache I felt when I was young?(13 is a just a random young age I guess).']])]

annotation:
[('You dig everything of which I’m ashamed
 There’s not anything to which you can’t relate
 And you’re still here', [['As opposed to the relationship presented in the previous song, “Spineless”, this song sees Alanis involved in a relationship that makes her grow to love herself for who she is. Her love interest helps her overcoming her shame about the things she doesn’t like about herself and he connects to her on many levels. As a results she’s learning how to accept herself too.

She remarks that “he’s still here”, almost as if she was surprised, meaning she’s never believed she could connect so much with someone and a relationship based on openness and sincerity could last this long.']]), ('You see everything, you see every part
 You see all my light and you love my dark', [['You know it’s true love when you find someone that sees every bit of yourself, your qualities and your faults, and they still make you feel accepted and loved.']])]

[Bridge]

[Verse 3]

You might also like[Chorus 1]
These excuses, how they served me so well
They've kept me safe
They've kept me stoic
They've kept me locked in my own cell

[Chorus 2]
