annotation:
[('Now my imagination is the only thing that limits
 The bar and its rise to the heights', [['She realizes that the only thing holding her back is her own thoughts and mindset.']]), ('Bringing these into light shakes their foundation
 And it clears my sight', [['Acknowledging her tendency to invent excuses and being dishonest with herself and the others around her helps her realizing that this is not the right thing to do and that she needs to get up and do something about it.']]), ('I’m too far from home
 It takes far too much energy
 And I cannot afford to
 No one will ever see me', [['That’s an excuse she tells herself to justify her distance and lack of contact with her family and loved ones. She uses her lack of time and energy as an excuse to not feel guilty about it.']]), ('And God wants me to work
 No resting, no lazy', [['Again, she shields herself from other people, this time by being a workaholic. She feels guilty that she doesn’t want to face her problems so she limits her life to work and she excludes fun and free-time activities that would feel “undeserved” for her.



God here is used an excuse to support her escapism from her reality through hard work. There are about 60 verses in the Bible referencing and supporting hard work in the name of God.']]), ('And there is not enough time
 It’s too hard to help me', [['She wants to discourage anyone who’s willing to help her by saying that she’s too damaged to be helped.

That is an excuse to not face her problems.']]), ('They’ll not understand me
 I am lonely, they’ll hate me', [['She avoids connection with other people, saying that they won’t understand her, that they will “hate her”.



That of course is an excuse not to get out of her shell and face her issues regarding having to do with new people and keeping in contact with her long-time friendships.']]), ('These excuses, how they served me so well
 They’ve kept me safe
 They’ve kept me stoic
 They’ve kept me locked in my own cell', [['In this song, her tendency exposed is to find excuses in order to keep herself isolated and not face interrelationship with other people.

The excuses kept her “stoic” in the sense that they kept her distant from her emotions and from the rest of the world. Here, “stoic” is used as a synonym of “apathetic”.



That shields her from any form of damage of suffering, at the price of being alone and not living life at its fullest.']])]

title: Thank U
lyrics:
Thank U Lyrics[Verse 1]
How 'bout getting off of these antibiotics
How 'bout stopping eating when I'm full up
How 'bout them transparent dangling carrots
How 'bout that ever elusive kudo

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence
[Verse 2]
How 'bout me not blaming you for everything
How 'bout me enjoying the moment for once
How 'bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
How 'bout grieving it all one at a time

[Chorus 1]
Thank you India
Thank you terror
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you frailty
Thank you consequence
Thank you, thank you silence

[Bridge]
The moment I let go of it
Was the moment I got more than I could handle
The moment I jumped off of it
Was the moment I touched down

[Verse 3]
How 'bout no longer being masochistic
How 'bout remembering your divinity
How 'bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
How 'bout not equating death with stopping
You might also like[Chorus 2]
Thank you India
Thank you providence
Thank you disillusionment
Thank you nothingness
Thank you clarity
Thank you, thank you silence

[Outro]
Yeah, yeah
Oh, oh, oh-oh
No, oh, oh, oh
No, oh, oh, oh12Embed
annotation:
[('Thank you India', [['In between Jagged Little Pill and Supposed former infatuation junkie. Alanis took a break and traveled to India. This song is a reflection of her trip.']]), ('How ’bout no longer being masochistic
 How ’bout remembering your divinity
 How ’bout unabashedly bawling your eyes out
 How ’bout not equating death with stopping', [["Again, the core of the song’s message, here we see a side that’s a tad darker. We are told to love ourselves and not be masochistic. “Remembering our divinity” is most likely about faith in embetterment, and that we can change if we believe enough.
Crying is, to most people, a very cathartic process and helps them get over the sadness and anger that they feel and reach a more serene state of mind. Alanis feels that we should be able to do so unapologetically.

The line about “not equating death with stopping” stems from one of Alanis' interviews. She said that when the tour for Jagged Little Pill was over, she finally sat in her room, doing nothing and she said she felt like she was dead, but a good kind of death. She now believes that we should not feel dead if we stop doing something that exhausts us, and that we should be thankful: firstly, for being able to do that thing in the first place; and secondly that we were able to stop."]]), ('How ’bout me not blaming you for everything
 How ’bout me enjoying the moment for once
 How ’bout how good it feels to finally forgive you
 How ’bout grieving it all one at a time', [['The whole song is a rumination of what we can and should do to better ourselves, and this is the core message of it. How about instead of blaming each others, we forgive, we enjoy life and all it has to offer. Sure, it won’t all be rainbows and butterflies, but living in the moment, not in the “what ifs” and “could’ve”, and just take life as it comes at us.']]), ('Thank you terror
 Thank you disillusionment
 Thank you frailty
 Thank you consequence
 Thank you, thank you silence', [['Here, Alanis acknowledges that everything that is a part of our lives helps us grow. A sort of a countinuation of “You Learn”’s theme, she thanks everything that made her the person she is today, while most people tend to dread these sorts of feelings.']]), ('How ’bout stopping eating when I’m full up
 How ’bout them transparent dangling carrots
 How ’bout that ever elusive kudo', [['Alanis muses over failings that people from western civilizations, and by extension, she herself, feels trapped in and that hat her mystical wanderings have brought to her attention, enabling her to begin to fix them.

We tend to “eat even when we’re full”, meaning that we love excesses, we love having a goal, and punishing ourselves over the things we “could have”. This is a very odd approach for what everyone pigeonholed Alanis to be: an angry woman, and it is a much more serene approach to life.']]), ('The moment I let go of it
 Was the moment I got more than I could handle
 The moment I jumped off of it
 Was the moment I touched down', [['Here the author realizes that she was trying to carry more she was able to.
When she let it go she could see it from a different perspective.']])]

For all that you are

annotation:
[('It’s all your fault', [['Another playful reversal. She’s lovingly teasing him as her way of thanking him. Obviously, he’s done nothing wrong—she’s not faulting him at all!']]), ('Head over feet', [['The main message of the song is about reversals, inversions, flipping the script to something unexpected: The title is a playful tweak of the idiom “head over heels,” which refers to being in love and “most likely developed from the literal meaning of falling upside down, as a way to describe the tumultuous emotions one feels while falling in love.”
https://writingexplained.org/idiom-dictionary/head-over-heels

Being in love is, from the perspective of the idiom, all about feeling turned upside down. It’s essentially about being surprised.

And yet the speaker tells her lover, “don’t be surprised.” (The effort to literally negate the surprise is itself another inversion!) Surprised about what? If she falls. Falls for him—in the typical somersault of giddy love described above? Not exactly. That kind of falling wouldn’t be surprising. Instead, she surprises him (and us) by tweaking the idiom:

While she doesn’t reverse the  imagery, she still manipulates the idiom away from what we expected. We expect to hear her say “head over heels,” but she surprises us—just as her experience of love has surprised her. For me, the imagery of “head over feet"—since it’s unfamiliar and thus doesn’t automatically evoke the same meaning as "head over heels"—seems less tumultuous than the original idiom suggests. Its plain meaning (while actually not really, on the surface, any different from the idiom that uses "heels”) seems to suggest the normal way we stand upright: our head is over our feet—the usual picture of standing “rightside up.” It’s actually about being grounded, standing tall (“feet planted firmly on the ground”), having a solid foundation for growth, for upward movement instead of chaotic tumbling—"ascending in love" as opposed to “falling in love.” So, while she says “don’t be surprised if I fall…”, she then, essentially, says that what will be surprising here will be the nature of the falling. It’ll be different—just like everything else in this relationship has been for her.']]), ('You’re my best friend
 Best friend with benefits', [['Believe it or not, this line is the origin of the infamous phrase that has made its way into the mainstream western vernacular, describing a relationship between two people that is sexual but not inherently long-term or romantic.']]), ('Your love is thick
 And it swallowed me whole
 You’re so much braver
 Than I gave you credit for
 That’s not lip service', [['talking about blowjobs folks!']]), ('You held your breath
 And the door for me', [['This is an example of zeugma. “Held” has a double meaning, one literal (“held the door”) and one metaphorical (“held your breath”).']])]

Everything Lyrics[Verse 1]

You see everything, you see every part

There's not anything to which you can't relate
And you're still here

[Verse 3]
I blame everyone else, not my own partaking

I'm terrified and mistrusting and you've never met anyone
Who's as closed down as I am sometimes

[Chorus]
You see everything, you see every part

You dig everything of which I'm ashamed
There's not anything to which you can't relate
And you're still here

[Bridge]
What I resist, persists
And speaks louder than I know

No matter how low or high I go
You might also like[Verse 4]
I am the funniest woman that you've ever known
I am the dullest woman that you've ever known

[Chorus]
You see everything (You see everything)
You see every part (You see every part)
You see all my light (You see all my light)
And you love my dark (And you love my dark)
You dig everything (You dig everything)
Of which I'm ashamed (Of which I'm ashamed)
There's not anything to which you can't relate
(There's not anything to which you can't relate)

(You see everything, you see every part)
And you're still here

annotation:
[('You dig everything of which I’m ashamed
 There’s not anything to which you can’t relate
 And you’re still here', [['As opposed to the relationship presented in the previous song, “Spineless”, this song sees Alanis involved in a relationship that makes her grow to love herself for who she is. Her love interest helps her overcoming her shame about the things she doesn’t like about herself and he connects to her on many levels. As a results she’s learning how to accept herself too.

She remarks that “he’s still here”, almost as if she was surprised, meaning she’s never believed she could connect so much with someone and a relationship based on openness and sincerity could last this long.']]), ('You see everything, you see every part
 You see all my light and you love my dark', [['You know it’s true love when you find someone that sees every bit of yourself, your qualities and your faults, and they still make you feel accepted and loved.']])]

title: Ironic
lyrics:
Ironic Lyrics[Intro]
Hey, yeah, yeah
Yeah, ah-ah-ah, yeah, hey

[Verse 1]
An old man turned ninety-eight
He won the lottery and died the next day
It's a black fly in your Chardonnay
It's a death row pardon two minutes too late

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Verse 2]
Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
And as the plane crashed down
He thought, "Well, isn't this nice?"

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Bridge]
Well, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
When you think everything's okay and everything's going right
And life has a funny way of helping you out
When you think everything's gone wrong
And everything blows up in your face
You might also like[Verse 3]
A traffic jam when you're already late
A "No Smoking" sign on your cigarette break
It's like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife
It's meeting the man of my dreams
And then meeting his beautiful wife

[Pre-Chorus]
And isn't it ironic?
Don't you think?
A little too ironic
And yeah, I really do think

[Chorus]
It's like rain on your wedding day
It's a free ride when you've already paid
It's the good advice that you just didn't take
And who would've thought? It figures

[Outro]
And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
Helping you out41Embed
annotation:
[('And who would’ve thought? It figures', [['Seemingly a throw-away line, the juxtaposition of these two contrary interjections neatly expresses the typical reaction to irony. An unexpected twist makes you say “Who would have thought?” but when you reflect it was almost inevitable (“It figures.”)']]), ('And yeah, life has a funny way of sneaking up on you
 And life has a funny, funny way of helping you out
 Helping you out', [['A bittersweet ending to a bittersweet song. Throughout the entire song, Alanis lists a number of sad, but at the same time, silly (and maybe sometimes ironic) situations that happen in people’s lives. The verses have a sad tone while the chorus is loud and cheerful. The outro says how helpless we are as human beings. We can plan our lives as much as we want but we can’t predict the future. We should accept that, and stop trying to control everything. Any little event can change the course of our entire life. What we should do is try to follow a certain path, but not be disappointed if we get sidetracked. That change of course might just be a blessing in disguise.']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?
 A little too ironic
 And yeah, I really do think', [['“Uh, no, we don’t,” said the English teachers of the world.

However, on the other hand, maybe the whole song really is ironic. Remember, irony is when things turn out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected. And Morrissette has just finished a song that is intended to illustrate the word “ironic” with a series of situations, except none of them actually turn out to be examples of irony. So the whole song turned out the opposite of how she expected.

In its own way, isn’t that ironic?']]), ('An old man turned ninety-eight
 He won the lottery and died the next day', [['It’s a pity that the old man, who had lived his whole life presumably in economical difficulty, had the chance to improve his lifestyle with a lottery win but he died the next day.

But is it ironic? No, it is not.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The old man had played the lottery specifically to get money to pay for heart surgery, but the excitement of finding out he’d won triggered a fatal heart attack.

Remember the definition of ironic:


using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny

strange or funny because something (such as a situation) is different from what you expected']]), ('It’s a black fly in your Chardonnay', [['Nobody wants a fly in anything they eat or drink, including a nice glass of white wine like Chardonnay. (Except of course people who enjoy eating insects.)

But that doesn’t make it ironic. Irony is when a situation turns out the opposite to what you’d planned or expected.

This MIGHT be ironic if:


You had deliberately decided to drink Chardonnay because you believed it was the beverage least likely to contain flies.
You had spent all day killing the flies in your home and, believing that you had successfully killed every single one of them, opened a bottle of Chardonnay to celebrate and discovered a fly in it.





Come on Alanis, it’s just protein!']]), ('It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife', [['Irish comedian Ed Byrne did a brilliant skit about “Ironic” back in 1998. He went to town on the lyrics, but saved his takedown of this line until last.

The best line in that song, the best line ever written, ever, has got to be the line ‘It’s like ten thousand spoons when all you need is a knife’. That’s not ironic – that’s just stupid. How big is your sink, Alanis? Come on![…]What do you need a knife for? To stab the bastard who keeps leaving spoons all over your house?

Byrne went on to give a scenario in which the line would make sense:

Imagine you needed a knife for something, couldn’t find one cos all you found was ten thousand spoons and therefore couldn’t do whatever it was you needed the knife for. And then the next day, turned out that a spoon would’ve done…

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZOZG1Ob6po']]), ('Mr. Play-It-Safe was afraid to fly
 He packed his suitcase and kissed his kids goodbye
 He waited his whole damn life to take that flight
 And as the plane crashed down
 He thought, “Well, isn’t this nice?”', [['More tragic than ironic.

This MIGHT be ironic if:
- The man was in a plane crash even though he had deliberately researched and chose an airline that was noted for its safety record, like Qantas.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qmF1Lh4f3OM

However, in the end, the song accidentally gets this one right.

That’s because when the man thinks to himself, “Well, isn’t this nice…?” he is thinking the opposite of what he means. Luckily for Morrissette, this fits the other dictionary definition of ironic:

using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny']]), ('And isn’t it ironic?
 Don’t you think?', [['A lot of people say no.

Even Alanis joked about it herself in the revisited version of the song performed on the Late Show with James Corden with the line: “It’s singing "Ironic,” but there are no ironies"']]), ('It’s a death row pardon two minutes too late', [['Now that just sucks – too bad they won’t ever have to know…

This is incredibly tragic and all too real. According to a study by Northwestern University, at least 39 innocent people have been wrongfully executed in the United States.

It is tragic, unjust, and worrisome. BUT – is it ironic? No.']])]

I'm guessing your thoughts again correctly
And I love
The way you press my buttons so much sometimes I could strangle you

annotation:
[('Papa, love your princess
 So that she will find loving princes familiar', [['She is sending a message to fathers, letting them know that if they do certain things and act a certain way towards their daughters then they will have better luck with men when they get older. Their daughters will know how a man is supposed to act and they’ll filter the bad ones out.']]), ('Please be a sexaholic
 Please be unpredictably miserable
 Please be self absorbed much (not the good kind)
 Please be addicted to some substance', [['At this point in the song, you’re probably thinking that Alanis is using sarcasm to get a point across, but that isn’t the case… Well not completely.

She understands that everyone has good and bad things about them, but no matter what, she still loves them. Her father was all of these things, but he was still her father and she appreciates his flaws.']]), ('Please be just like my', [['This entire song Alanis has been explaining what she looks for in a man because her father showed her what a real man looks like.

This song is a tribute to her father. He may have passed on, and she misses him dearly.']])]

annotation:
[('Can’t go to you for consolation', [['You can’t go back to someone you jus break up with.']]), ('This grief overwhelms me
 It burns in my stomach
 And I can’t stop bumping into things', [['In a conversation with SongwriterUniverse in 2006, Alanis stated that this was the saddest song that she has ever written:

“Simple Together” is the saddest song that I’ve ever written hands down. There’s a simplicity and directness to it ‘the most distilled version of sadness I’ve ever put into a song.’”']])]

title: That I Would Be Good
lyrics:
That I Would Be Good Lyrics[Verse 1]
That I would be good even if I did nothing
That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down
That I would be good if I got and stayed sick
That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds
That I would be fine even if I went bankrupt
That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth
That I would be great if I was no longer queen
That I would be grand if I was not all knowing

[Chorus]
That I would be loved even when I numb myself
That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
That I would be loved even when I was fuming
That I would be good even if I was clingy
[Verse 2]
That I would be good even if I lost sanity
That I would be good whether with or without you

[Outro]
I, I would
I, IYou might also like2Embed
annotation:
[('That I would be good if I lost my hair and my youth', [['Many critics of Morissette’s blockbuster first album were frequently impressed at the startling maturity, insight, and honesty of her lyrics from such a young songwriter, which might well have caused her to wonder if they’d find her as impressive in a few years, when she seemed less a prodigy.']]), ('That I would be loved even when I numb myself
 That I would be good even when I am overwhelmed
 That I would be loved even when I was fuming
 That I would be good even if I was clingy', [["The song acts as a sort of prayer or mantra that Alanis feels represents her current state, as of writing the album. While it may seem downbeat and sad, the song stems from a place of hope and vulnerability. The absence of the predicate leaves the song open to interpretation. The general vibe of the song begs for something along the lines of “I pray” or “I hope”, however it is up to the listener entirely.  Probably one of Alanis' most heartfelt."]]), ('That I would be grand if I was not all knowing', [['I think this is a wink to religion, or religous people. God can be viewed  upon as all-knowing. Here, the word ‘grand’ is used as superlative to good and great and is not surpassed in these lyrics, thus being the highest possible.

So the line states ‘being not surpassed, but not all-knowing’. This hints at a God that might not be all-knowing, but still the grandest power we know.

It subtly says that even the highest power might have a blind spot and that being ‘good’, ‘great’ or ‘grand’ remains relative and subjective.']]), ('That I would be good if I got and stayed sick', [['One of the most sensitive, delicate lines in this song, referring to being incurable ill. Some views hold that being in this condition is something one has called upon itself due to bad lifestyle for example.
Others view that the acceptance of having an incurable disease is the same as giving up the fight, to resign. People are expected to ‘fight’ diseases like cancer to the end. Alanis here asks herself is this is the only way to be viewed as ‘good’.

Alanis emphasizes here that having an incurable disease and accepting it, might be a good thing.']]), ('That I would be good even if I gained ten pounds', [['Since appearance is an important thing in western culture and gaining weight is often considered a bad thing, Alanis refers to the issues surrounding weight gain that could bring people to adapt their eating pattern/lifestyle into something they do, not because they want to, but because others want them to.']]), ('That I would be good even if I got the thumbs down', [['Again, referring to the pressure others can put onto you by expressing their view/opinion.
Alanis refers to critics who would give a thumb down to something she created with passion and love. She’s not into music to create crappy songs, still it might not please everyone, especially those who think they know what she should sing/write/produce.']]), ('That I would be good even if I did nothing', [['The opening line of the song refers to the pressure western culture brings to its people. We are expected constantly be doing things, being busy.
Doing nothing is not considered  a virtue in western culture, but it really can strain people.
Alanis kicks off with this line, because after the success of “Jagged Little Pill”, people were constantly breathing down her neck for new material, which she could only produce after taking a long time off.']])]

Hands Clean Lyrics[Verse 1]

[Pre-Chorus]

We'll fast forward to a few years later

Ooh, this could get messy, but

annotation:
[('Ooh, this could get messy
 But, ooh, you don’t seem to mind
 Dude, don’t go telling everybody
 And overlook this supposed crime', [["Supposed crime definitely refers to statutory rape. During an interview for The New York Times, Alanis was asked about the interpretation of the song as sexual exploitation.

‘'It could be categorized as that,’‘ Morissette said, ’‘But at the same time, I’m not one to really categorize. I’m the kind of person that will say 'a person that I’ve been spending time with in a romantic way’ rather than saying ‘my boyfriend.’ So I’ll say ‘someone that I was romantically linked to at a time when I was emotionally not necessarily prepared for it,’ as opposed to qualifying it as like ‘statutory rape.’ ‘’"]]), ('If it weren’t for your maturity, none of this would’ve happened
 If you weren’t so wise beyond your years, I would’ve been able to control myself
 If it weren’t for my attention, you wouldn’t have been successful, and if
 If it weren’t for me, you would never have amounted to very much', [['The verses of this song seem to be Alanis repeating phrases that her much older lover would say about their secret relationship. In this first verse, she recites how he justified himself: it’s her fault for acting so much older than she is and being so irresistible, that she’s learning from him and wouldn’t get anywhere in life without him.

The language itself exhibits textbook grooming and victim blaming.']]), ('You’re essentially an employee and I like you having to depend on me
 You’re a kind of protégé, and one day, you’ll say you learned all you know from me, and', [['These lines suggest the man was also in the music industry. While she is young, he is helping to guide her and teach her to be successful in the industry. This also gives him an air of power and intelligence, making him more amazing in her eyes.']]), ('And I know you depend on me like a young thing would to a guardian
 I know you sexualize me like a young thing would, and I think I like ya', [['The older man she’s in a relationship with enjoyes wielding influence over her, which reinforces an imbalanced power dynamic in the relationship inherent with their age difference. It is common for young people to become infatuated with older people; he realizes this and takes full advantage of it.

It is also telling that he refers to Alanis as a “young thing” rather than a “young woman.” In a sense, that language is dehumanizing her and referring to her as an object rather than a person.']]), ('Ooh, this could be messy, and
 Ooh, I don’t seem to mind, and
 Ooh, don’t go telling everybody
 And overlook this supposed crime', [['The first time it is said the man doesn’t mind how badly everything could end. This time around, Alanis is saying she also doesn’t seem to care. She is so infatuated with this man, it’s hard to see the consequences of their actions.']]), ('I wish I could tell the world ’cause you’re such a pretty thing when you’re done up properly
 I might wanna marry you one day, if you watch that weight and keep your firm body', [['More things he told her. He would leave her on about their future. “I wish I could tell everyone about us…”, “One day, maybe we’ll get married..” And Alanis in her youth & naivete believes everything sincerely.']]), ('Just make sure you don’t tell on me, especially to members of your family
 We best keep this to ourselves and not tell any members of our inner posse', [['They know each other’s friends and family, but because they know it’s wrong to be together, the man keeps telling Alanis to keep quiet as its a secret. Her being younger, does everything he says because she believes he knows best.']]), ('What part of our history’s reinvented and under rug swept?
 What part of your memory is selective and tends to forget?
 What with this distance, it seems so obvious?', [['Sweeping things under the rug is a way of hiding the “dirty” or “unwanted” things in our life from other people’s sight. She feels their whole past has been swept under the rug and re-invented as an innocent story i.e. “Ohh, I knew Alanis when she was a young budding musician. She showed great promise and I was her musical mentor” vs. the passionate story of love she wants to tell. She feels he’s forgotten and moved on, and as the two of them grow further apart, she sees his selfish actions more and more clearly.']]), ('And I’ve more than honored your request for silence
 And you’ve washed your hands clean of this', [['Here she reiterates that she’s kept her silence as requested, but she is becoming exasperated, “I’ve MORE than done what you asked”. She needs to talk to someone about this, and writing a song was her chosen outlet method.']]), ('We’ll fast forward to a few years later
 And no one knows except the both of us
 And I have honored your request for silence
 And you’ve washed your hands clean of this', [['Years later, the affair has ended. He has told her not to tell anyone. She clearly feels hurt about the way it ended, and the fact that only the two of them know and she can’t talk to anyone about it, leaves her feeling empty and as if the affair meant nothing in the end. He was older so she just did as he asked, trusting he knew what was best. But he has walked away from everything with no consequences, and her being younger, is bearing it all alone.']])]

title: Hand in My Pocket
lyrics:
Hand in My Pocket Lyrics[Verse 1]

I'm sick, but I'm pretty, baby
You might also like[Chorus 4]

Well, I've got one hand in my pocket
And the other one is playin' a piano

[Chorus 5]

Is that everything is just fine, fine, fine
'Cause I've got one hand in my pocket
And the other one is hailin' a taxi cab18Embed
annotation:
[('Cause I’ve got one hand in my pocket
 And the other one is flickin’ a cigarette', [['This may be a reference (and it is certainly a near direct quote [holding, instead of flickin] from) Hitchcock’s 1940 film “Rebecca,” in which Laurence Olivier describes the posture of his titular ex-wife in a pivotal scene as such. It fits with the ironic paradoxes framed in the verses, as it suggests a completely self possessed and determined woman, who is still teetering on the edge of her own demise.']]), ('I’m sick, but I’m pretty, baby', [['In a recent documentary “Music Box”, Alanis discusses her struggles over the years with an eating disorder that began from other’s perception of her body although she was already quite thin when first starting her music career at a young age. So she’s sick but, according to others, she’s pretty so that makes it worth it.']]), ('’Cause I’ve got one hand in my pocket
 And the other one is hailin’ a taxi cab', [['This line is fitting as the last in the song, as it signifies her leaving the setting (if there is one). It is almost as if she were talking to the listener in person, giving them updates on her life.']]), ('[Bridge]', [['Alanis is credited with playing harmonica on this song – as well as “All I Really Want” and “Head Over Feet” from the same album – which she plays in the bridge.']]), ('I’m broke, but I’m happy
 I’m poor, but I’m kind
 I’m short, but I’m healthy, yeah
 I’m high, but I’m grounded
 I’m sane, but I’m overwhelmed
 I’m lost, but I’m hopeful, baby', [['The verses of the song see Alanis explore different paradoxes of her personality and her status in life.

In the first verse, she says that despite having no money, she is quite content with her life and she is still kind, meaning that she’s not greedy or too attached to material things.

She’s not quite tall, but she still accepts her body for what it is and feels healthy.

She’s high, probably meaning she dreams a lot and her expectations exceed reality, but at the same time she tries to stay with one foot on the ground and remain realistic.

Also, she’s overwhelmed and under a lot of pressure, and she might feel lost like everybody else at times, but she is still optimistic about the future.']])]

title: So Unsexy
lyrics:
So Unsexy Lyrics[Verse 1]
All these little rejections, how they add up quickly
One small sideways look and I feel so ungood
And somewhere along the way, I think I gave you the power to make
Me feel the way I thought only my father could

One forgotten birthday, I'm all but cooked

So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind

[Chorus]

So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind

[Bridge]
When will I stop leaving, baby?
When will I stop deserting, baby?
When will I start staying with myself?

[Verse 3]
All these little projections, how they keep springing from me
I jump my ship as I take it personally
And all these little rejections, how they disappear quickly
The moment I decide not to abandon me

[Chorus]
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mind
I can feel so unsexy for someone so beautiful
So unloved and for someone so fine
I can feel so boring for someone so interesting
So ignorant for someone of sound mindYou might also like1Embed
annotation: [('I jump my ship', [['The captain that abandons ship at the first sight of tribulation is something that has been seen time and time again. Alanis may be running away from her problems the moment she feels the ship sinking, but also may be neglecting her problems and mental health by to dealing with them. The only way she will able to progress is by facing the trial head-on and not deflecting.']]), ('I think I gave you the power to make\n Me feel the way I thought only my father could', [['A lot of women’s relationships with their fathers set up the premise for their dating life and in this lyric, Alanis is telling us that this guy is reminiscent of her father in a negative way. It brings her back to her childhood and the emotions that are tied to her father.']]), ('All these little rejections, how they seem so real to me', [['Though these rejections may be something that is in her head and overanalyzing, it still fells like the real deal and hurts her in such a vivid way']]), ('I’m 13 again, am I 13 for good?', [['Will I ever grow past the heartache I felt when I was young?(13 is a just a random young age I guess).']])]

annotation:
[('And yes, they’re in shock, they are panicked', [['the wish of the friend to end their life has come as a shock to everyone around them.']]), ('Dear darlin’, your mom, my friend
 Left a message on my machine
 She was frantic, saying you were talking crazy
 That you wanted to do away with yourself
 Guess she thought I would be the perfect resort
 ’Cause we’ve had this inexplicable connection since our youth', [['A friend’s mother called Alanis in hopes that she could talk some sense into her daughter who was obviously feeling at the end of her rope with life.']]), ('If we were our bodies
 If we were our futures
 If we were our defenses
 I’d be joining you
 If we were our culture
 If we were our leaders
 If we were our denials
 I’d be joining you', [['The chorus is repeated three times throughout the song and each time she lists things that belong to the material world — such as body, success, emotions, culture, leaders etc, but since we are greater than those things, Alanis tries to convince her friend to not commit a suicide.

She doesn’t specifically says what we are, since it goes beyond human physical experiences and definitions.

So, she’s saying if we were merely those earthly things, she’ll joining you and commit a suicide too, but we’re more than that, don’t do it.']])]

annotation:
[('I grow from a special seed', [['Human beings start out as eggs inside a woman’s womb. They are like seeds who grow into babies that come out of the womb during Labour.']]), ('My punishments are consequences', [['The law of Karma will settle with people’s deeds.']]), ('My yearn for home is broadened
 Patriotism expanded
 By callings from beyond', [['She went further the definition of patriotism and now she’s a patriot of the world.']]), ('As I cut the cord of home
 I kiss my mother’s mother
 Look to the horizon', [['Her vision of the world has changed during the years. Staring at the horizon, she remains graceful to her parents, she kisses her grandmother, but now what she calls a home is the entire world and that makes her a citizen of the world.']]), ('My president is Guanyin', [['Guanyin is the buddhist Goddess of Mercy and she is associated with compassion. Her name means “Observing the Cries of the World”.
Alanis is basically saying that her statute is compassion.']]), ('From French and Hungarian snow', [['Her father has French-Irish origins while her mother was of Hungarian ancestry.']])]

annotation:
[('I’ll be your keeper for life, as your guardian
 I’ll be your warrior of care, your first warden
 I’ll be your angel on call, I’ll be on demand
 The greatest honor of all, as your guardian', [["Havoc and Bright Lights was written just after Alanis gave birth to her first child, Ever.



Alanis said the song could be about a child-parent relationship, about a friendship or even about herself.

I think it really shows how the parent/guardian angel role are linked… how, ultimately, a powerful inner parent calls upon spirit to guide her/his choices on the loved ones' behalf… whether it is for a child, a friend, or an inner child… this love and this grace is available to everyone."]])]

annotation:
[('Mississippi', [['From Mississippi, you go North and cross the border into Memphis —\xa0home of Elvis’s Graceland mansion.']]), ('Black velvet if you please', [['The pause between ‘black velvet’ and ‘if you please’ that throws the 4/4 time signature of the song off for a moment was intentionally added by Myles. She explained to The Badger in 2018:

Count the number of beats in the space between “black velvet" and “if you please”. You’ll note they’re all uneven numbers, intentionally. I sang either a 5/4 bar or a 6/4 bar to where the listener would not expect because the length of the hole felt right for me to land or start in an odd place to create pathos or tension then a pay off … I was influenced by Lowell George (drummer and singer) from the Atlanta band, Little Feat. Odd bar counts all over the place. It drove everyone crazy, they thought I couldn’t count to four until they heard the results.']]), ('White lightning', [['White lightning is another name for moonshine. Moonshiners were prevalent in Tennessee.

In addition, Elvis was one of the first white crooners who brought the sound and soul of black musicians to the masses.']]), ('Black velvet', [['Elvis was a popular subject for “velvet painting”, a folk-art form consisting of acrylic paint on a black-velvet canvas.

Also, Elvis’s smooth voice was often characterized as “velvet”.']]), ('Mama’s baby’s in the heart of every schoolgirl', [['In this case, “Mama’s baby’s” is referring to Elvis, and every “schoolgirl” had Elvis in their “heart”.']]), ('On the Victrola up high', [['“Victrola” was a trademarked name for a line of record players manufactured by Victor Talking Machine Company (now called RCA Records) between 1906 and 1960.  The word became something of a genericized trademark (e.g. “Frigidaire”, “Kleenex”, “Escalator”, and “Aspirin”) meaning any sort of record player.']]), ('“Love Me Tender” leaves ‘em cryin’ in the aisle', [['Love Me Tender was the first film Elvis Presley starred in, in 1956. The school girls cry “in the aisle” (at the movie theater) because Presley’s character is killed at the end of the film.

It is also the title of one of Presley’s singles released to promote the film. “Love Me Tender” was released in 1956, and topped the Billboard Charts and unseated the previous number 1 single (also by Presley) “Hound Dog.”

Elvis famously performed the song in 1956 on the Ed Sullivan show, where he was filmed from the waist up due to his dancing and gyrating. At the time his movements were considered suggestive and lewd, and known to send the girls in the audience (and millions more at home) into a screaming frenzy.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zaHZsW3wX_0']]), ('The sun is settin’ like molasses in the sky', [['The sun seems to be taking forever to go down, slow like molasses. Molasses is viscous at low temperatures and famously flows very slowly, to the point that “slow as molasses” is a common phrase in regions were molasses is popular as a food, including the American South, where this song is set. She wants the relief of night to ease the heat of the day.

This is also a reference to the color a summertime sunset in Mississippi.']]), ('The boy could sing
 Knew how to move, everything', [['Elvis’s talent was clear from an early age, and he was greatly inspired by both gospel music and the black R&B scene he encountered in Memphis. “Move, everything” is a reference to the way Elvis would shake his hips, making women swoon.']]), ('In a flash, he was gone
 It happened so soon', [['Presley’s death in 1977 was a sudden and dramatic event, so sudden that some people believe him to be still alive.']])]

annotation:
[('Mississippi', [['From Mississippi, you go North and cross the border into Memphis —\xa0home of Elvis’s Graceland mansion.']]), ('Black velvet if you please', [['The pause between ‘black velvet’ and ‘if you please’ that throws the 4/4 time signature of the song off for a moment was intentionally added by Myles. She explained to The Badger in 2018:

Count the number of beats in the space between “black velvet" and “if you please”. You’ll note they’re all uneven numbers, intentionally. I sang either a 5/4 bar or a 6/4 bar to where the listener would not expect because the length of the hole felt right for me to land or start in an odd place to create pathos or tension then a pay off … I was influenced by Lowell George (drummer and singer) from the Atlanta band, Little Feat. Odd bar counts all over the place. It drove everyone crazy, they thought I couldn’t count to four until they heard the results.']]), ('White lightning', [['White lightning is another name for moonshine. Moonshiners were prevalent in Tennessee.

In addition, Elvis was one of the first white crooners who brought the sound and soul of black musicians to the masses.']]), ('Black velvet', [['Elvis was a popular subject for “velvet painting”, a folk-art form consisting of acrylic paint on a black-velvet canvas.

Also, Elvis’s smooth voice was often characterized as “velvet”.']]), ('Mama’s baby’s in the heart of every schoolgirl', [['In this case, “Mama’s baby’s” is referring to Elvis, and every “schoolgirl” had Elvis in their “heart”.']]), ('On the Victrola up high', [['“Victrola” was a trademarked name for a line of record players manufactured by Victor Talking Machine Company (now called RCA Records) between 1906 and 1960.  The word became something of a genericized trademark (e.g. “Frigidaire”, “Kleenex”, “Escalator”, and “Aspirin”) meaning any sort of record player.']]), ('“Love Me Tender” leaves ‘em cryin’ in the aisle', [['Love Me Tender was the first film Elvis Presley starred in, in 1956. The school girls cry “in the aisle” (at the movie theater) because Presley’s character is killed at the end of the film.

It is also the title of one of Presley’s singles released to promote the film. “Love Me Tender” was released in 1956, and topped the Billboard Charts and unseated the previous number 1 single (also by Presley) “Hound Dog.”

Elvis famously performed the song in 1956 on the Ed Sullivan show, where he was filmed from the waist up due to his dancing and gyrating. At the time his movements were considered suggestive and lewd, and known to send the girls in the audience (and millions more at home) into a screaming frenzy.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zaHZsW3wX_0']]), ('The sun is settin’ like molasses in the sky', [['The sun seems to be taking forever to go down, slow like molasses. Molasses is viscous at low temperatures and famously flows very slowly, to the point that “slow as molasses” is a common phrase in regions were molasses is popular as a food, including the American South, where this song is set. She wants the relief of night to ease the heat of the day.

This is also a reference to the color a summertime sunset in Mississippi.']]), ('The boy could sing
 Knew how to move, everything', [['Elvis’s talent was clear from an early age, and he was greatly inspired by both gospel music and the black R&B scene he encountered in Memphis. “Move, everything” is a reference to the way Elvis would shake his hips, making women swoon.']]), ('In a flash, he was gone
 It happened so soon', [['Presley’s death in 1977 was a sudden and dramatic event, so sudden that some people believe him to be still alive.']])]

It drove everyone crazy, they thought I couldn’t count to four until they heard the results.']]), ('White lightning', [['White lightning is another name for moonshine. Moonshiners were prevalent in Tennessee.

In addition, Elvis was one of the first white crooners who brought the sound and soul of black musicians to the masses.']]), ('Black velvet', [['Elvis was a popular subject for “velvet painting”, a folk-art form consisting of acrylic paint on a black-velvet canvas.

Also, Elvis’s smooth voice was often characterized as “velvet”.']]), ('Mama’s baby’s in the heart of every schoolgirl', [['In this case, “Mama’s baby’s” is referring to Elvis, and every “schoolgirl” had Elvis in their “heart”.']]), ('On the Victrola up high', [['“Victrola” was a trademarked name for a line of record players manufactured by Victor Talking Machine Company (now called RCA Records) between 1906 and 1960.  The word became something of a genericized trademark (e.g. “Frigidaire”, “Kleenex”, “Escalator”, and “Aspirin”) meaning any sort of record player.']]), ('“Love Me Tender” leaves ‘em cryin’ in the aisle', [['Love Me Tender was the first film Elvis Presley starred in, in 1956. The school girls cry “in the aisle” (at the movie theater) because Presley’s character is killed at the end of the film.

It is also the title of one of Presley’s singles released to promote the film. “Love Me Tender” was released in 1956, and topped the Billboard Charts and unseated the previous number 1 single (also by Presley) “Hound Dog.”

Elvis famously performed the song in 1956 on the Ed Sullivan show, where he was filmed from the waist up due to his dancing and gyrating. At the time his movements were considered suggestive and lewd, and known to send the girls in the audience (and millions more at home) into a screaming frenzy.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zaHZsW3wX_0']]), ('The sun is settin’ like molasses in the sky', [['The sun seems to be taking forever to go down, slow like molasses. Molasses is viscous at low temperatures and famously flows very slowly, to the point that “slow as molasses” is a common phrase in regions were molasses is popular as a food, including the American South, where this song is set. She wants the relief of night to ease the heat of the day.

This is also a reference to the color a summertime sunset in Mississippi.']]), ('The boy could sing
 Knew how to move, everything', [['Elvis’s talent was clear from an early age, and he was greatly inspired by both gospel music and the black R&B scene he encountered in Memphis. “Move, everything” is a reference to the way Elvis would shake his hips, making women swoon.']]), ('In a flash, he was gone
 It happened so soon', [['Presley’s death in 1977 was a sudden and dramatic event, so sudden that some people believe him to be still alive.']])]

title: The Free Electric Band
lyrics:
The Free Electric Band LyricsMy father is a doctor, he's a family man
My mother works for charity whenever she can
And they're both good clean Americans who abide by the law
And they both stick up for liberty and they both support the war

My happiness was paid for when they laid their money down
For summers in a summer camp and winters in the town
My future in the system was talked about and planned
But I gave it up for music and The Free Electric Band

I went to school in hand-washed shirts with neatly ordered hair
And the school was big and newly built and filled with light and air
And the teachers taught us values that we had to learn to keep
And they'd clip the ear of any idle kid who went to sleep
And my father organised for me a college in the east
But I went to California, the sunshine and the beach
My parents and my lecturers could never understand
Why I gave it up for music and The Free Electric Band

Well, they used to sit and speculate upon their son's career
A lawyer or a doctor or a civil engineer
Just give me bread and water, put a guitar in my hand
Cause all I need is music and The Free Electric Band

My father sent me money and I spent it very fast
On a girl I met in Berkeley in a social science class
Yes, and we learnt about her body but her mind we didn't know
Until deep rooted attitudes and morals began to show

She wanted to get married even though she never said
And I knew her well enough by now to see inside her head
She'd settle for suburbia and a little patch of land
So I gave her up for music and The Free Electric Band

The Free Electric Band

title: The Free Electric Band
lyrics:
The Free Electric Band LyricsMy father is a doctor, he's a family man
My mother works for charity whenever she can
And they're both good clean Americans who abide by the law
And they both stick up for liberty and they both support the war

My happiness was paid for when they laid their money down
For summers in a summer camp and winters in the town
My future in the system was talked about and planned
But I gave it up for music and The Free Electric Band

I went to school in hand-washed shirts with neatly ordered hair
And the school was big and newly built and filled with light and air
And the teachers taught us values that we had to learn to keep
And they'd clip the ear of any idle kid who went to sleep
And my father organised for me a college in the east
But I went to California, the sunshine and the beach
My parents and my lecturers could never understand
Why I gave it up for music and The Free Electric Band

Well, they used to sit and speculate upon their son's career
A lawyer or a doctor or a civil engineer
Just give me bread and water, put a guitar in my hand
Cause all I need is music and The Free Electric Band

My father sent me money and I spent it very fast
On a girl I met in Berkeley in a social science class
Yes, and we learnt about her body but her mind we didn't know
Until deep rooted attitudes and morals began to show

She wanted to get married even though she never said
And I knew her well enough by now to see inside her head
She'd settle for suburbia and a little patch of land
So I gave her up for music and The Free Electric Band

title: It Never Rains in Southern California
lyrics:
It Never Rains in Southern California Lyrics[Verse 1]
Got on board a westbound seven forty-seven
Didn't think before deciding what to do
Ooh, that talk of opportunities
TV breaks and movies
Rang true, sure rang true

[Pre-Chorus]
Seems it never rains in southern California

[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours

[Verse 2]
Out of work, I'm out of my head
I'm out of self respect, I'm out of bread
I'm under-loved, I'm underfed
I wanna go home

[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours

[Verse 3]
Will you tell the folks back home I nearly made it?
Had offers but didn't know which one to take
Please don't tell 'em how you found me
Don't tell 'em how you found me
Gimme a break, give me a break

[Pre-Chorus]
Seems it never rains in southern California
Seems I've often heard that kind of talk before
You might also like[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours3Embed
annotation:
[('It never rains in California
 But girl, don’t they warn ya?
 It pours, man, it pours', [['Of course, it rains in California (northern, central, or southern). In fact, it does indeed pour. But So Cal’s myth has always been its perfect weather, so the narrator is warning others not to make the same mistake he did by believing the hype.']]), ('Out of work, I’m out of my head
 I’m out of self respect, I’m out of bread
 I’m under-loved, I’m underfed
 I wanna go home', [['The narrator finds himself unemployed, broke, and losing his mind. He’s getting desperate to go back home.']]), ('Didn’t think before deciding what to do
 Ooh, that talk of opportunities
 TV breaks and movies
 Rang true, sure rang true', [['The opening verse sets the scene for the whole song. It shows all the opportunities that he saw from the outside, whilst also showing the regret of what chasing those those false opportunities led him to become. He admits that he was young, and didn’t think about the consequences of leaving, and what it would change in his life.']]), ('Seems it never rains in southern California
 Seems I’ve often heard that kind of talk before
 
 [Chorus]
 It never rains in California
 But girl, don’t they warn ya?
 It pours, man, it pours', [['The grass always appears greener on the other side. Sometimes the grass may even be greener, but only because it’s always raining. By drastically juxtaposing the first verse, the chorus explains the realisation that this place that was perfect in his head is not as perfect as it seems. All of the opportunities in the music industry are there, but they come at a cost. A cost that is often hidden when looking in from the outside']]), ('Got on board a westbound seven forty-seven', [['He took a Boeing 747 jet to California']]), ('Will you tell the folks back home I nearly made it?
 Had offers but didn’t know which one to take
 Please don’t tell ’em how you found me
 Don’t tell ’em how you found me', [['He doesn’t want mom, dad and all his friends to be dissapointed, so asks somebody to let them know he ‘almost made it’

‘Don’t tell them how you found me’  suggests depression and/or substance abuse.']])]

title: It Never Rains in Southern California
lyrics:
It Never Rains in Southern California Lyrics[Verse 1]
Got on board a westbound seven forty-seven
Didn't think before deciding what to do
Ooh, that talk of opportunities
TV breaks and movies
Rang true, sure rang true

[Pre-Chorus]
Seems it never rains in southern California
Seems I've often heard that kind of talk before
[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours

[Verse 2]
Out of work, I'm out of my head
I'm out of self respect, I'm out of bread
I'm under-loved, I'm underfed
I wanna go home

[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours

[Verse 3]
Will you tell the folks back home I nearly made it?
Had offers but didn't know which one to take
Please don't tell 'em how you found me
Don't tell 'em how you found me
Gimme a break, give me a break

[Pre-Chorus]
Seems it never rains in southern California
Seems I've often heard that kind of talk before
You might also like[Chorus]
It never rains in California
But girl, don't they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours3Embed
annotation:
[('It never rains in California
 But girl, don’t they warn ya?
 It pours, man, it pours', [['Of course, it rains in California (northern, central, or southern). In fact, it does indeed pour. But So Cal’s myth has always been its perfect weather, so the narrator is warning others not to make the same mistake he did by believing the hype.']]), ('Out of work, I’m out of my head
 I’m out of self respect, I’m out of bread
 I’m under-loved, I’m underfed
 I wanna go home', [['The narrator finds himself unemployed, broke, and losing his mind. He’s getting desperate to go back home.']]), ('Didn’t think before deciding what to do
 Ooh, that talk of opportunities
 TV breaks and movies
 Rang true, sure rang true', [['The opening verse sets the scene for the whole song. It shows all the opportunities that he saw from the outside, whilst also showing the regret of what chasing those those false opportunities led him to become. He admits that he was young, and didn’t think about the consequences of leaving, and what it would change in his life.']]), ('Seems it never rains in southern California
 Seems I’ve often heard that kind of talk before
 
 [Chorus]
 It never rains in California
 But girl, don’t they warn ya?
 It pours, man, it pours', [['The grass always appears greener on the other side. Sometimes the grass may even be greener, but only because it’s always raining. By drastically juxtaposing the first verse, the chorus explains the realisation that this place that was perfect in his head is not as perfect as it seems. All of the opportunities in the music industry are there, but they come at a cost. A cost that is often hidden when looking in from the outside']]), ('Got on board a westbound seven forty-seven', [['He took a Boeing 747 jet to California']]), ('Will you tell the folks back home I nearly made it?
 Had offers but didn’t know which one to take
 Please don’t tell ’em how you found me
 Don’t tell ’em how you found me', [['He doesn’t want mom, dad and all his friends to be dissapointed, so asks somebody to let them know he ‘almost made it’

‘Don’t tell them how you found me’  suggests depression and/or substance abuse.']])]

My mother works for charity whenever she can
