annotation:
[('I’m in the middle without any plans
 I’m a boy and I’m a man', [['He’s in the middle- neither young nor old. Neither an adult nor a child. Or perhaps both of those things.']]), ('I got a baby’s brain and an old man’s heart', [['A baby’s brain, because he is still irresponsible, but an old man’s heart, because he lived as much difficulties (heartbreaks?) as old people']]), ('I’m eighteen', [['Bob Erzin, the man who helped make this song a hit originally misheard the lyrics as “I’m edgy!”, bothering the band members tremendously. Perhaps this was because Alice Cooper was 23 when he recorded the song.']]), ('[Verse 1]', [['Originally this song was 8 minutes long and was played live in tandem with a psychedelic reel of gory pictures. Unofficial 6th member of the band Bob Erzin helped them trim it down to a neat 2:56 seconds.']]), ('Eighteen, eighteen and I like it', [['Johnny Rotten sang this song when he auditioned for Sex Pistols.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MN2uhTo-rQ']]), ('Eighteen, I just don’t know what I want
 Eighteen, I gotta get away
 I gotta get out of this place, I’ll go runnin in outer space, oh yeah', [['It addresses the inner conflicts of a typical teenager who becomes an adult once he reaches 18. There is confusion about his life goal and what he wants to achieve as a man. He enjoys the newly gained freedoms of adulthood, but has no clues on what to do. He doesn’t want to face reality, such that he wants to escape from the real world. The Alice Cooper group wrote this song during the Vietnam war and eighteen was the age that was old enough to be enrolled but not old enough to vote. There is the American dream deep in his heart, to have freedom of choosing what he does instead of being in the army, and of expressing his own opinions to society.']])]

annotation: [('Yeah, billion dollar baby\n I got you in a dimestore', [['Before the Great Inflation of the 1970s, stores that specialized in cheap stuff were called nickel & dime stores.  Nowadays, they’re usually called dollar stores.']]), ('Billion dollar baby', [["“Billion dollar baby” was the title of a moderately successful 1945 Broadway show, but the song’s title is more likely referring to a common theme of Alice Cooper songs: that children and young adults are unjustly treated as though they were their parents' property."]])]

title: Devil's Food
lyrics:
Devil’s Food LyricsGet ready for the lady
She's gonna be a treat
Simmer slightly 'til ready
Make her soft too
Make her sweet

I kiss the tears off from your chest
I felt the poison fright that's in your breath
I knew your precious life and I know your death
I squeeze the love out of your soul
All the perfect love that's in your soul
You're just another spirit on parole
Devil's food
(You are) Devil's food
(You are) Devil's food

"Leaving Lepidoptera – please don't touch the displays, little boy; so cute – moving to the next aisle we have arachnida: the spiders, our finest collection. This friendly little devil is the Heptophilidae, unfortunately harmless. Next to him, the nasty Lycosa Raptoria; his tiny fangs cause creeping ulcerations of the skin. And here, my prize, the Black Widow. Isn't she lovely? And so deadly. Her kiss is fifteen times as poisonous as that of the Rattlesnake. You see, her venom is highly neuro-toxic, which is to say that it attacks the central nervous system - causing intense pain, profuse sweating, difficulty in breathing, loss of consciousness, violent convulsions and finally death. You know, I think what I love the most about her is her inborn need to dominate, possess. In fact, immediately after the consummation of her marriage to the smaller and weaker male of the specie, she kills and eats him. Oh, she is delicious, and I hope he was. Such power and dignity unhampered by sentiment. If I may put forward a slice of personal philosophy; I feel that Man has ruled this world as stumbling, demented child-king long enough, and as his empire crumbles my precious Black Widow shall rise as his most fitting successor."You might also likeEmbed
annotation:
[('I squeeze the love out of your soul
 All the perfect love that’s in your soul
 You’re just another spirit on parole', [['Steven may be singing about his wife in this part.  It is mentioned that he abuses his wife, or in other words “[squeezes] the love out of [her] soul”.  More about Steven’s abuse is mentioned in “Only Women Bleed”.']]), ('I feel that Man has ruled this world as stumbling, demented child-king long enough,', [['Eric Harris, one of the two Columbine High School shooters, reportedly had these lines as a quote on his AOL member profile.

Following the massacre, Cooper was interviewed on Phoenix, Arizona’s KTAR Radio to promote his career retrospective box set, coincidentally released April 20, 1999- the same day as the massacre. During this interview, Cooper explained that the song was about a black widow spider and nothing else.']]), ('She’s gonna be a treat', [['Possibly a foreshadowing of horror icon Vincent Price’s upcoming speech about the mating rituals of black widow spiders, albeit with the gender reversed. It is the male spider who is a treat for the female spider.

Or, it could be, you know… An innuendo.']]), ('And here, my prize, the Black Widow. Isn’t she lovely?', [['This mention of the Black Widow spider is building up to the track that follows “Devil’s Food”.']]), ('Next to him, the nasty Lycosa Raptoria; his tiny fangs cause creeping ulcerations of the skin.', [['Lycosa Raptoria is part of the genus of wolf spiders, which includes the European Tarantula Wolf Spider.']]), ('”Leaving Lepidoptera – please don’t touch the displays, little boy; so cute –', [['This spoken section of the song narrated by Vincent Price takes the form of a professor leading Steven through a collection of preserved invertebrates. Lepidoptera refers to the order of insects encompassing butterflies and moths.

The insects on the background of the album cover allude to this idea of preserved invertebrates.']])]

annotation: [('For making us doubt our parent’s authority', [['Alice is well known as being the king of shock-rock, which was a large part of American teenager counter-culture in the 1970s. The lifestyle around said teenagers generally included a disdain for their own parents and their authority over them as individuals.']]), ('Drinking alcohol constantly', [['From the 1970s up to 1984, Alice Cooper had an addiction to alcohol, of which he is now open about in interviews. After being hospitalized more than once for alcoholism and dropped from his record label, he got sober.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For criminal acts and violence on the stage', [['By 1976, Cooper’s stage shows had already involved hangings, guillotine executions, and grotesque stage props.']])]

annotation: [('I love Detroit ’cause I was born to fight', [['Detroit is the hometown of Alice Cooper, who was born Vincent Furnier in the Motor City on February 4, 1948']]), ('I love the Tigers but I hate the Mets', [['When considering that “Loving the Tigers” (like Detroit native Cooper does in real life) while simultaneously “Hating the Mets” is an odd concept since the American League Tigers and National League Mets never faced each other in a World Series and would not face each other until Interleague play started in 1997, it becomes apparent that Cooper wrote the line in order to complete a rhyme.']]), ('Homemade pie', [['Pie was brought to America by the first English settlers in the 17th century. Also, there is a saying of being “as American as apple pie” dating back to the 1900s.']]), ('I love Old Glory', [["‘Old Glory’ is the nickname of the United States' flag."]]), ('I love my chicken Kentucky Fried...\n Finger Lickin’ Good!', [['A little shout-out to one of America’s most notable fast-food chains, Kentucky Fried Chicken, or KFC.']]), ('I think them Ruskies should be sterilized', [['An offensive slur for native-born Russians. In this song, Cooper advocates for making it so that Russians not be able to reproduce.']]), ('I love that mountain with those four big heads', [['Referring to Mount Rushmore, located in South Dakota’s Black Hills National Forest. From left to right, it depicts George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln.']])]
